questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is undergoing pubertal changes. Her tanner stage is stage 4 for breast development and pubic hair scale. Which of the following pubertal changes is not due to estrogen?
questions.solution:
Pubarche or development of axillary and pubic hair is not due to estrogen. It is due to testosterone (in both the sexes).

Puberty in females :

  • Involves the beginning of menstrual cycles (menarche), breast development (thelarche), and an increase in adrenal androgen secretion (adrenarche).
  • Estradiol induces the development of secondary sex characteristics, including the breasts and reproductive tract, and increased fat in the hips.
  • Estrogens also regulate the growth spurt at puberty, vaginal cornification and cervical mucus production, induce closure of the epiphyses, have a positive effect in maintaining bone formation, and can antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone on bone.

In young girls before puberty the vaginal epithelium is thin and comprised of only basal and parabasal layers. During the reproductive years, the vaginal epithelium thickens and develops a distinct cornified layer due to the influence of estrogen. Cervical mucous production and menstruation are also changes occuring under the influence of estrogen and also progesterone.

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and edema. On examination, JVP was elevated. Gross examination finding of the tissue biopsy is shown. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of ascites, and edema with elevated JVP points towards congestive hepatopathy. The image shows a nutmeg liver and chronic passive congestion of the liver. it usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

Pathogenesis:

  • It is seen in patients with chronic cardiac lesions, especially those affecting the right heart (e.g., right-sided heart failure), which causes the blood to be damped back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins.
  • This leads to increased pressure in the sublobular branches of the hepatic veins, which causes an engorgement of venous blood.

Gross appearance:

  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion due to heart failure, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • The appearance is called the nutmeg liver pattern due to its close resemblance with the cut surface of the nutmeg seed.

The image below liver with gross appearance as described above along with cut section of the nutmeg seed on top left corner.

Microscopic appearance:

Microscopic examination reveals centrilobular hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with renal tubular damage caused by one of his chemotherapeutic drugs. Which drug could it be?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of nephrotoxicity and is one of the dose-limiting toxicity of cisplatin therapy. Cisplatin achieves a high concentration in nephrons. Both direct toxicity and inflammation are responsible for nephrotoxicity. A high concentration of chloride stabilizes cisplatin and reduces nephrotoxicity. Therefore, chloride diuresis is used to reduce nephrotoxicity.

Cisplatin is a platinum coordination complex that enters cells by the high-affinity Cu2+ transporter CTR1 and thus degrade the transporter. Inside the cell, the chloride, cyclohexane, or oxalate ligands of the analogues are displaced by water molecules, yielding a positively charged molecule that reacts with nucleophilic sites on DNA and proteins.

  • Used with paclitaxel, induces complete response in the majority of patients with carcinoma of the ovary
  • Cisplatin produces responses in cancers of the bladder, head and neck, cervix, and endometrium
  • All forms of carcinoma of the lung; anal and rectal carcinomas; and neoplasms of childhood.
  • The drug also sensitizes cells to radiation therapy and enhances control of locally advanced lung, esophageal, and head and neck tumors when given with irradiation.

  • Left subclavian lymph trunk

  • Left bronchomediastinal lymph trunk

The lymph passes through larger lymphatics and eventually collect into two large trunks, the thoracic duct and right lymphatic duct, which in turn drain into the brachiocephalic veins.

questions.text: If the diameter of an artery was found to be reduced to one-third. By what value does the resistance of the artery increase?
questions.solution:
The resistance increases by 81 times.

The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius of the tube is expressed by the Poiseuille-Hagen formula.

Airflow can be derived from Poiseuille- Hagen formula: 

Q =π ΔPr4/8ηL

Where

  • Q is the flow rate
  • π is pie symbol
  • ΔP is the pressure difference
  • r is radius
  • η is viscosity
  • L is length

Also,

Flow rate (Q) = pressure difference (ΔP)/ resistance (R).

Therefore, substituting this in Poiseuille- Hagen formula,

ΔP/ R = π ΔPr4/8ηl

1/R = π r4/8ηl

R = 8ηl/ π r4

Therefore it can be derived that airway resistance is inversely proportional to the radius by the power of four.

In the given question, the diameter is reduced to one-third. So, the radius is also reduced to one-third. Hence, vessel resistance will increase by 34 or 81 times.

With Poiseuille- Hagen formula we might feel that the smallest airways are the major site of resistance. However, the contribution by the smallest airways is very little to the overall total resistance. This is because, the airway branches in each generation exist in parallel rather than in series. As the parallel branching increases, the resistance decreases. (Total cross-sectional diameter of small airways put together is high). Thus the overall resistance of the small airways is very small. Also, airflow velocity decreases substantially as the effective cross-sectional area increases (i.e., the flow becomes laminar).

Other factors affecting airway resistance :

  • Lung volume, as lung volume increases the resistance decreases and vice versa. Lung volume increases the transairway pressure thus increasing the caliber of the airway.
  • Airway mucus, edema, and contraction of bronchial smooth muscle increase the airway resistance. Its clinical application is seen in asthma, bronchitis, and emphysema
  • The density and viscosity of inspired gas also contribute to airway resistance. A gas with more density imparts more resistance.

questions.text: A research study is being conducted on patients in rehabilitation where the impact of addiction among young adults was assessed on their subsequent divorce. Among two groups of study subjects, divorced and non-divorced, the history of alcohol or drug use was assessed. What kind of study is being done here?
questions.solution:
The above study design is typical of a case-control study. Here the divorced group acts as a case study group while the non-divorced group acts as a control group.

  • A case-control study uses individuals as the unit.
  • The study proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.
  • This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference.
  • A nested case-control study is a case-control study nested in a cohort study and it is a type of cohort study which moves in the forward direction.

    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to detect blood stains?
questions.solution:
Barberio's test is not used for detecting blood stains. It helps in the identification of semen.

Barberio's test is used to detect the presence of spermine picrate, a component of prostatic secretion. A drop of the stain of spermatic fluid taken in a glass slide is charged with a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid. Under microscopic examination, the needle-shaped yellowish spermine picrate crystals indicate the presence of semen.

Option B: Takayama's test- It is also known as the hemochromogen crystal test. It is a more reliable test to detect old blood stains. 2-3 drops of Takayama's reagent are added to the suspected material on the glass slide. A positive test result is indicated by the presence of pink feathery crystals of reduced hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin in clusters.

Option C: Teichman's test- This test is also used to detect blood stains. It is also called as hemin crystal test. A small crystal of sodium chloride and glacial acetic acid is used for the test. Faint yellowish-red to brownish crystals of hemin or hematin chloride in clusters are seen if the suspected material is stained with blood. Teichman's test may be negative if the blood stain is old. 

Option D: Spectroscopy-  It is the most reliable test to detect the presence of both old and recent blood stains. Characteristic dark bands are produced depending on the type of blood pigment when the blood solution is examined under a spectroscope.

questions.text: A given drug has a bioavailability of 30%. What does this mean?

choices.text: 30% percent of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in unchanged form
The drug is 30 percent potent in producing  therapeutic effec
30 percent of the drug undergoes first pass metabolism in Liver
The drug is 30 percent pure in its chemical  composition

questions.solution:
If a drug has a bioavailability of 30%, it means that only 30% of the drug reaches the systemic circulation in its original, unchanged form after it is administered. The remaining 70% of the drug may undergo various processes such as metabolism, degradation, or excretion before it reaches the bloodstream.

Bioavailability is defined as the fraction of a drug reaching systemic circulation in an unchanged form after administration by any route. The area under the blood concentration-time curve (AUC) is proportional to the dose and the extent of bioavailability for a drug.

Bioavailability (F) = Quantity of drug reaching systemic circulation/Quantity of drug administered

Bioavailability depends on two factors, absorption and 1st pass metabolism. The bioavailability of the drug injected intravenously is 100%. However it is lower after oral ingestion because of incomplete absorption and first-pass metabolism in the intestinal wall or liver and lies between 5% to <100%. The bioavailability of subcutaneous and intramuscular routes lies between 75% to ≤100%.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the casualty with a sudden loss of vision and painful ocular movements. questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a sudden painful loss of vision in the absence of fundoscopic changes, RAPD and central scotoma is suggestive of optic neuritis, specifically retrobulbar neuritis. 

There are 3 types of optic neuritis: papillitis, neuroretinitis, and retrobulbar neuritis. The common causes of retrobulbar neuritis include demyelinating disorders such as multiple sclerosis (MS) and neuromyelitis optica (NMO or Devic's disease).

Clinically, optic neuritis is characterized by sudden, progressive visual loss.  Ocular movements are painful in retrobulbar neuritis and painless in papillitis and neuroretinitis. Glowing sensations known as phosphenes may be induced with sound or movement. Color vision may also be impaired. 

On examination, Marcus Gunn pupil or relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is usually noted due to asymmetric involvement. The most common visual field defect is a central or centrocecal scotoma.

The clinical vignette describes Meig's syndrome, it is an acquired disorder without genetic association.

Conservative surgery (salpingo-oophorectomy) is done. The clinical features resolve on resection of the fibroma.

questions.text: A patient presented with cheilitis, stomatitis, and a glove and stocking pattern of neuropathy. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for this clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation described, including cheilitis, stomatitis, and glove and stocking pattern neuropathy, is most consistent with Vitamin B12 deficiency. This deficiency can lead to a condition known as pernicious anemia which presents with a variety of symptoms including those described.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurological manifestations such as peripheral neuropathy (glove and stocking pattern), as well as gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea. Additionally, vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia, which may present with cheilitis and stomatitis.

Other options:

(a) Niacin (B3) deficiency: Niacin deficiency can lead to a condition called pellagra, which is characterized by the "3 Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Cheilitis and stomatitis are common manifestations of pellagra, but glove and stocking pattern neuropathy are not typically associated with niacin deficiency.

(b) Thiamine (B1) deficiency: Thiamine deficiency can cause a condition known as beriberi, which can manifest with neurological symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, but it usually does not present with dermatological symptoms like cheilitis and stomatitis.

(d) Riboflavin (B2) deficiency: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency can cause glossitis (inflammation of the tongue) and cheilosis (cracks or sores at the corners of the mouth). While riboflavin deficiency can cause dermatological symptoms, it is less likely to cause rashes in sun-exposed areas and peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: DNA is present in?
questions.solution:
Mitochondria are membrane-bound organelles found in eukaryotic cells. They have their own small circular DNA, known as mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA), which encodes a limited number of genes.

mtDNA is inherited maternally and is essential for the synthesis of certain proteins involved in energy production through oxidative phosphorylation.

The presence of DNA in mitochondria is a key characteristic that distinguishes them from other cellular structures.

Other Options:

  • Lysosome: Cellular organelles containing enzymes that degrade cellular waste and foreign substances. 

  • Cytoplasm: Region within a cell that surrounds the nucleus and organelles. While some cellular activities occur in the cytoplasm, DNA is primarily housed in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells.

  • Endoplasmic reticulum: Complex network of membranes involved in protein synthesis, lipid metabolism, and calcium storage. It does not typically contain DNA.

questions.text: You are working as an internal medicine consultant at a private clinic. A patient with chronic renal disease requiring hemodialysis is admitted under you. You advise diet and fluid control and keep him under observation. However, the patient progresses to take ayurvedic supplements and sometimes skips the your instructions without disclosing it. His conditions worsen and he develops difficulty in breathing. His attendant files a complaint in court alleging the negligence of the doctor. Which of the following acts as a defence for the doctor in court?
questions.solution:
In the given case, since the patient did not adhere to the proper instructions of the doctor, it was partly or wholly his fault. This is termed contributory negligence. Proper documentation as to how ordinary care was not exercised on part of the patient can be useful in a court of law.

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred

Other options:

Option A: Vicarious liability is not a defence against professional negligence. Vicarious liability (liability for the actions of another): An employer is responsible not only for his own negligence but also for the negligence of his employees.

Option B: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on part of the doctor eg: leaving behind a scalpel or scissor whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: Therapeutic misadventure may serve as a defence against negligence. It basically refers to an adverse outcome that could not have been anticipated despite reasonable care. eg: a rare side effect of a drug or blood loss due to an anomalous artery despite exercising caution.

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: Identify the hormones 1 and 2 in the following image
questions.solution:
The image shows the Hypothalamic pituitary axis and the hormones 1 is Inhibin and 2 is testosterone.

Hypothalamus stimulates the Anterior pituitary via GnRh to release FSH and LH.

LH stimulates Leydig cells to secrete testosterone, which in turn inhibits LH by a negative feedback mechanism. FSH stimulates Sertoli cells to secrete inhibin, which in turn inhibits FSH by a negative feedback mechanism.

Testosterone inhibits LH secretion by acting directly on the anterior pituitary and by inhibiting the secretion of GnRH from the hypothalamus. Inhibin acts directly on the anterior pituitary to inhibit FSH secretion.

FSH also stimulates the secretion of ABP (androgen-binding protein). FSH and androgens maintain the gametogenic function of the testes. Hypothalamic lesions in animals and hypothalamic disease in humans lead to atrophy of the testes and loss of their function.

questions.text: Which among the following parasites directly invade the skin?
questions.solution:
The parasite that directly invades the skin is Schistosoma mansoni.

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria. Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in a serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, and hepatosplenomegaly.

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose.

A yellowish-brown egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end is suggestive of Schistosoma mansoni. In Schistosoma hematobium, the egg has a terminal spine. In Schistosoma japonicum, the egg has no spine but shows a lateral small rudimentary knob.

The life cycle of schistosomes is represented below:

Other options:

Option B: Dracunculiasis/Guinea worm disease is a vector-borne parasitic disease caused by Dracunculus medinenesis. Transmission occurs by consumption of water containing cyclops harboring infective stages of the parasite. This disease is totally a water-based disease and has no alternate way of transmission.

Option C: Wuchereria bancrofti causes filariasis. The adult worms block the lymphatic vessels leading to inflammation and granuloma formation. This causes hard pitting or brawny edema. It can present as lymphadenitis, lymphedema, hydrocele, and elephantiasis. The disease spreads from person to person through mosquito bites.

Option D: Onchocerca volvulus is a tissue nematode. The life cycle of Onchocerca volvulus is completed partly in humans, the definitive host, and partly in female blackflies, the intermediate host. During a blood meal, the female blackfly ingests the microfilariae from the skin and lymphatics of an infected person. Within the vector, the microfilariae develop into the infective stage. When the infected black fly bites another person, it introduces third-stage filarial larvae into the skin of the human host.

questions.text: Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is:
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for tachycardia during right atrial distension is Bainbridge Reflex.

The stretch receptors of the atria that elicit the Bainbridge reflex transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Then efferent signals are transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase heart rate and strength of heart contraction. Thus, this reflex helps prevent damming of blood in the veins, atria, and pulmonary circulation.

Other options:

Option A: Bezold–Jarisch Reflex: Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region causes profound brady­cardia, hypotension and a brief period of apnoea followed by rapid shallow breathing.

Option C: Cushing Reflex: When intracranial pressure is increased, the blood supply to Rostral Ventro-Lateral Medulla (RVLM) neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia cause an increase in discharge from the neurons, producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

Option D: J Reflex: The stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) causes apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia, and hypotension.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic female who was treated with steroids and remdevisir for COVID now presented with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose. On examination, blackish necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is a non-contagious fungal disease most commonly caused by Rhizopus oryzae that is acquired through the inhalation of fungal spores from air. It may occur during COVID infection or after a few weeks (usually around the 3rd week) of recovery from it. Reasons for increase in mucormycosis cases in COVID patients are:

  • Uncontrolled hyperglycemia due to any reason. COVID per se has a tendency to worsen diabetes and also precipitate diabetes in previously normal individuals. 
  • Misuse and irrational use of steroids. Steroid overuse can cause new-onset diabetes.
  • Leucopenia associated with COVID
  • Prolonged ICU stay, unhygienic humidifiers, and irrational use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Pre-existing comorbidities such as hematological malignancies, use of immunosuppressants, and solid organ transplantation.

A high index of suspicion is required for the early diagnosis of mucormycosis. Checklist of sentinel signs/ symptoms of mucormycosis to be monitored in patients admitted with COVID-19 are:

  1. Relatively early disease (Nose and sinuses):
    • Headache and nasal obstruction (especially if severe or persistent and not responding to medications)
    • Nasal crusting, brownish or blood-tinged nasal discharge
    • Facial pain, pain over sinuses
    • Paraesthesia/ loss of sensation over half of the face
    • Discoloration of the skin or localized facial puffiness
    • Loosening of teeth, discoloration, ulceration, or eschar over the palate
  2. Moderately advanced disease (Eye/orbital involvement):
    • Eye swelling or redness, eye pain
    • Double vision, drooping of the eyelid, blurring, and loss of vision.
  3. Very advanced disease (Intracranial involvement):
    • Involvement of cranial nerves II-VI suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis
    • Signs of MCA thrombosis 

Diagnosis:

  • KOH mount and microscopy
  • Histopathology of debrided tissue shows presence of ribbon-like aseptate hyphae (5-15 µ thick) branching at right angles.
  • Culture can be done but treatment should be started on clinical suspicion.
  • CT of sinuses, CT chest for suspected pulmonary involvement ( presence of more than 10 nodules, reverse halo sign are highly suggestive of mucor), and MRI brain to look for the extent of intracranial involvement.

Management:

  • Treatment of co-morbid illness and strict glycemic control.
  • Anti-fungal therapy started early on high clinical suspicion even prior to microbiological confirmation can reduce mortality. Treatment involves a combination of surgical debridement and antifungal therapy.
  • Liposomal Amphotericin B (5-10mg/kg) is the drug of choice and has to be continued for 3-6 weeks. It should be diluted in 5% dextrose and is incompatible with normal saline and Ringer lactate. Step-down therapy to be done with oral posaconazole or isavuconazole. Renal function must be monitored during the entire treatment period.
  • Early surgical debridement after stabilization of systemic illness and ensuring facilities for post-surgical care and ventilation.

Other options:

Option A: Invasive aspergillosis leads to the formation of black or greyish membrane in the nasal mucosa. The maxillary sinus may contain a fungus ball containing semisolid cheesy-white or blackish material.

Option C: Foreign body nose presents with foul-smelling unilateral discharge.

Option D: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis, and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of vertical diplopia upon climbing downstairs. On examination, he tilts his head on his shoulder while going downstairs. Which is the cranial nerve involved?

The correction effort by the patient will be in line with the direction of action of the weak muscle.   • Four recti muscles - Superior, inferior, medial, and lateral recti
  • Two obliques - Superior and inferior oblique

The muscles originate from the back of the orbit in a common tendinous ring called the annulus of Zinn and are inserted into the sclera.

All the extraocular muscles (including inferior oblique) are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

  • Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

questions.text: Which of the following surgeries use this instrument?

The given image is that of a Bone punch and it is used in dacryocystorhinostomy (DCR) operation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the mechanism of action of thiazides in DCT?

choices.text: Inhibits the Na-CI pump in early distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-CI pump in late distal convoluted tubule
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the descending limb of loop of Henle
Inhibits the Na-K-2Cl pump in the ascending limb of loop of Henle

questions.solution:
Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the Na+/Cl- co-transporter.

Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide-like diuretic. It inhibits the Na Cl symporter in the early distal tubule and increases the excretion of sodium and chloride.

Thiazide diuretics:

They may be used for the treatment of hypertension, heart failure, nephrolithiasis due to idiopathic hypercalciuria, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Thiazides act on the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). They block the NaCl co-transporter in the DCT. This results in the loss of sodium, chloride, and water contributing to the diuretic effect. The diuretic effect of thiazide leads to decreased osmotic pressure due to the loss of Na+, Cl-, and water leading to compensatory reabsorption of uric acid thus resulting in hyperuricemia. The intracytoplasmic Na+ concentration also decreases due to the blockade of the co-transporter. To compensate, the Na+/Ca2+ exchanger pumps sodium from the systemic circulation into the epithelial cells in exchange for calcium. The declining calcium levels inside the cell will draw more calcium from the lumen into the systemic circulation. This results in hypercalcemia. There is also increased loss of Mg2+, K+, and H+.

Mechanisms of antihypertensive action: Decreases plasma and ECF volume by diuresis thereby decreasing cardiac output. Even when the compensatory mechanisms restore the Na+ levels and plasma volume, a low BP is maintained by a reduction in total peripheral resistance. This reduction in total peripheral resistance is due to the persistence of a small sodium and volume deficit even after compensation. The decreased intracellular sodium is responsible for increased compliance of the vessel wall and a reduced response to constrictor stimulus.

Thiazides are the diuretic of choice for uncomplicated hypertension.

Advantages of thiazide as an antihypertensive are:

  • It can be given as once a day dose and has a flat dose-response curve
  • Decreased incidence of postural hypotension and relative freedom from CNS side effects
  • No tolerance
  • No fluid retention
  • Decreased risk of osteoporotic fractures due to its hypocalciuric action
  • Low cost
  • Effectiveness in isolated systolic hypertension
  • Thiazides are ineffective both as antihypertensive and diuretic in patients with chronic renal failure.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency department complaining of severe pain in her right index finger, back and legs along with fatigue. She states that the pain began suddenly about six hours ago. On examination, the patient appears pale and is grimacing in pain. A peripheral blood smear confirms the presence of sickle-shaped red blood cells. The biochemical analysis revealed high levels of indirect bilirubin. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right upper quadrant, and there is diffuse tenderness in the joints. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a Sickle cell crisis, which is a complication of Sickle cell anemia.

Sickle cell anemia is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to the point mutation in the β-globin gene, which results in the replacement of glutamate residue with valine. This causes the production of sickle-shaped red blood cells due to the polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin (HbS). 

Factors that predispose to sickling are infection, dehydration, and acidosis.

The clinical features of sickle cell disease are due to the tendency of HbS molecules to stack into polymers when deoxygenated.

Clinical features:

  • Moderately severe hemolytic anemia with jaundice
  • Painful bone crisis - hand-foot syndrome or dactylitis of the bones of hands and feet.
  • Acute chest syndrome - Typically presents with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates.
  • Hyposthenuria- inability to concentrate urine.
  • The aplastic crisis stems from the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient cessation of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.
  • Spleen In children- splenic sequestration crises occur which results in splenomegaly due to red pulp congestion.
    - Adolescence or early adulthood- auto splenectomy occurs due to splenic infarction, fibrosis, and progressive shrinkage.
    - Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococcal, meningococcal, and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia, can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics.
  • Other clinical features- priapism, leg ulcers, stroke, retinopathy, pigment gallstones, and growth retardation.

The diagnosis is suggested by the clinical findings, the presence of irreversibly sickled red cells on the peripheral smear, and hemoglobin electrophoresis showing increased HbA2 and HbF and S spike. The changes in the skull resemble a crewcut in radiographic studies as a result of compensatory erythroid hyperplasia.

questions.text: A patient who presents to the OPD has a visual field defect as shown below. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma marked as 3 in the image given. 

Options marked in the image are:

1. Left optic nerve 
3. Otic chiasma
4. Left optic tract 
5. Left lateral geniculate nucleus

Hemianopia or hemianopsia refers to loss of sight in half the visual field. Bitemporal hemianopia refers to loss of sight in the temporal halves of the visual field, seen in lesions affecting the optic chiasma. The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours. Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, and suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

Damage to the middle part of the optic chiasm affects fibres crossing at the nasal retina of each eye, leaving the uncrossed fibres from the temporal retinas intact. The resulting loss of vision is confined to the temporal visual field of each eye and this is known as bitemporal hemianopia. It is also called heteronymous hemianopia to emphasize the fact that the parts of the visual field that are lost in each eye do not overlap.

Individuals with this condition are able to see in both left and right central visual fields, with both eyes open. However, all information from the most peripheral parts of visual fields (which are seen only by the nasal retinas) is lost.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: Defective Tyrosine transaminase is associated with _____.
questions.solution:
Defective Tyrosine transaminase is associated with type II tyrosinemia, known as Oculocutaneous tyrosinemia.

There are three types of tyrosinemias:

  • Type 1 tyrosinemia: also known as hepatorenal tyrosinemia is an autosomal recessive condition. The defective enzyme is fumaryl acetoacetate hydrolase. Clinical features are liver failure, hypoglycemia, boiled cabbage odor in the urine, and mental retardation. 
  • Type 2 is known as oculocutaneous tyrosinemia or Richner-Hanhart syndrome. The defective enzyme is tyrosine transaminase. Clinical features are palmoplantar keratosis, painful corneal erosions, photophobia, and mental retardation.
  • Type 3 is known as neonatal tyrosinemia. It is due to the deficiency of 4-Hydroxyphenylpyruvate hydroxylase. Clinical features include normal liver function, developmental delay, seizures, and intermittent ataxia.

Alkaptonuria is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of an enzyme homogentisate oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissue resulting in ochronosis. Due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogenetic acid, it shows a characteristic blackening of urine on standing for a long time or black stain in diapers. They often present in the third to the fourth decade of life.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound and typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as a/an ___________________
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound

The characteristics of a lacerated wound:

The margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate a direction, in which the blow or force was applied. Depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibers. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

 Swallow tail in a Lacerated wound

 

Fishtails - These may be seen in stab wounds where the skin splits at the corner. 

Chop wounds: called because of the action in which they are produced. Depending on the type of instrument, they may resemble an incised or a lacerated wound. The shape of the wound may give clues to the type of weapon. For example, in the given image, the wound resembles an injury produced by a sharp axe. Such wounds may be inflicted with homicidal intent on the skull/scalp. Chop wounds are usually deep gaping wounds caused by a blow with the sharp cutting edge of a fairly heavy weapon like an axe, sword, hatchet etc

questions.text: What is the reason that hemoglobin cannot pass through the glomerulus in a normal physiological state?

choices.text: It is a large molecule bounded with another protein.
It gets attracted to the positive charge of the glomerular filtration barrier.

questions.solution:
The haemoglobin (Hb) cannot pass through the glomerulus in a normal physiological state because it is a large molecule bound with another protein.

The Hb molecule released into the blood from RBCs is immediately bound by a protein called haptoglobin (size: 12.4 nm). It forms the haemoglobin-haptoglobin complex which is large enough to be prevented from crossing the glomerular filtration barrier.  

Free haemoglobin undergoes extensive glomerular filtration, which is blocked by Haptoglobin. The filtration of Hb leads to renal tubule iron deposition (brown) and hemoglobinuria. This is prevented by the sequestration of Hb by haptoglobin.

Another reason is because of the negative charge of Hb. Both the Hb and glomerular filtration barrier are negatively charged. Hence Hb is repelled away from the filtration barrier. 

The glomerular filtration barrier consists of:

  • The endothelium of the capillary
  • A basement membrane - contains type IV collagen, glycosaminoglycan heparan sulfate which has a negative charge. 
  • A layer of epithelial cells (podocytes) surrounding the outer surface of the capillary basement membrane.

The capillary endothelium is perforated by thousands of small holes called fenestrae, which measure from 4 nm up to 8nm. Therefore, neutral substances with molecular diameters of less than 4 nm are freely filtered, and filtration of those with diameters of more than 8 nm approaches zero.

In addition to the size of the particles, the filtration also depends mainly on the charge of the particle being filtered. The glomerular capillary wall consists of highly negatively charged proteins called sialoproteins, which repel the negatively charged substances (anions). The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which will repel most of the negative charges (anionic substances). Whereas, the cationic substances are easily filtered.

questions.text: A 42-year-old HIV patient presented with altered sensorium and impaired consciousness. India Ink examination shows positive results. Which organism is most likely to be responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the positive India ink stain suggests the diagnosis of Cryptococcus neoformans infection.

C. neoformans spreads from inhalation of the yeast cells in pigeon faeces causing infection in HIV/AIDS and other immunosuppressive conditions. In causes influenza-like respiratory infection in immunocompetent persons. In immunocompromised it disseminates to CNS causing cryptococcal meningoencephalitis and patients may complain of headaches, neck stiffness, and disorientation as in this case. Other common sites of dissemination include the skin, adrenals, bone, eye, and prostate gland.

Cryptococcal meningitis is the most common cause of meningitis in an immunocompromised HIV patient. It presents with subacute meningoencephalitis with fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs. The CSF profile shows elevations in WBC with lymphocyte predominance, elevated protein levels, and reduced to normal levels of glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated      

Diagnosis is made by demonstration of yeast cells or cryptococcal antigen in CSF. India ink stain is used to demonstrate capsulated budding yeast cells in CSF as they have a distinctive appearance because their capsules exclude ink particles (shown below). Rapid detection of cryptococcal antigen in CSF and blood can also be done. Colonies develop within a few days on most media at room temperature or 37°C. Media with cycloheximide should be avoided as it inhibits Cryptococcus.

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

Other Options:

Options A and B: The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

Option C:  Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus. It is a facultative intracellular parasite. Yeast form occurs mainly in tissues at a temperature of 37oC and mycelial form occurs in soil at 25oC. Spores are found in bird or bat droppings in the soil which acts as reservoir of infection. Transmission occurs via inhalation of conidia. Person-to-person transmission or animal-to-man transmission is not yet known.

questions.text: A government plans to outline tobacco control laws. What is the level of prevention here?

Creating tobacco control laws is a method of primary prevention.

Making tobacco control laws targets smokers who are already exposed to risk of smoking, who have not yet developed any disease. This aims to reduce smoking which is essentially a reduction of risk factor which is a primary prevention stratergy.

Primary prevention is defined as an action taken prior to the onset of disease, whose aim is to prevent the disease from occuring. Its target population is healthy individuals. It commonly institutes activities that limit risk exposure or increase the immunity of individuals at risk to prevent a disease from progressing in a susceptible individual. They approaches can be as follows:

  • Population (mass) strategy where the target group is the whole population
  • A high-risk strategy where the target group is limited to the people who are most at risk of developing a particular disease.

questions.text: A truck driver comes with complaints of a painless indurated genital ulcer after unsafe intercourse. Which of the following investigations can be used to diagnose the causative organism?

questions.text: A young female patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. A diagnosis of Myasthenia gravis is made. What is the preferred treatment for this patient at this stage?
questions.solution:
Intermittent ptosis is considered one of the earliest signs of Myasthenia gravis. Pyridostigmine is the preferred treatment for symptomatic patients at this stage of the disease.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder that is characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular junction. Failure of transmission results in muscle weakness. Hence the goal is to increase the duration of action of acetylcholine by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase. The most commonly used anticholinesterase drug is pyridostigmine. 

Females are more commonly affected than males and the disease tends to occur in middle age.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Muscle weakness and fatiguability increase with repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep. Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetrical
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis 
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of the palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Deep tendon reflexes are intact
  • Myasthenic crisis - acute exacerbation of muscle weakness especially intercostal and diaphragmatic muscles resulting in ventilatory failure. It is most commonly due to infection and anticholinesterase medication overuse.

Myasthenia gravis is associated with thymoma and other autoimmune diseases such as Hashimoto's thyroiditis, Grave's disease, Neuromyelitis optics, Systemic lupus erythematosus, etc.

Diagnosis:

  • Ice-pack test - application of ice pack over the eyes improves ptosis (decreases the activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and increases transmission).
  • Antibodies associated with myasthenia gravis: Anti-AChR antibodies, Anti-MuSK antibodies, Anti-LRP4 antibodies
  • Repetitive nerve stimulation test shows a decremental response.
  • Edrophonium chloride or Tensilon test - improvement of symptoms occurs on injecting edrophonium. Edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. This increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft and improves transmission.

Treatment:

  • Symptomatic treatment: Anticholinesterase agents – Pyridostigmine is the initial therapy of choice.
  • Chronic immunomodulating therapy: Glucocorticoids (prednisone) and immunosuppressive drugs (azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine) implemented in patients significantly symptomatic on pyridostigmine.
  • Rapid immunomodulating treatment: IVIG and therapeutic plasma exchange—Used to tide over severe illness (myasthenic crisis) and as 'bridge' therapy before surgery, or starting chronic immunomodulating treatment.
  • Surgical approach: Thymectomy

questions.text: Which among the following functions is not carried out by the intestinal epithelium?
questions.solution:
Bile salts are not secreted by the intestinal epithelium. They are secreted by the liver.

The intestinal epithelium has multiple roles to be performed in the functioning of the gastrointestinal system.

  • Absorptive function: provides surface area and mechanisms for absorption of digestive products
  • Secretory function: intestinal digestive enzyme secretion
  • Protective function: both formation of the physical barrier and chemical barrier via the production of mucous

Bile salts are secreted by the liver from cholesterol.

questions.text: A tall obese person, who is a known hypertensive was recently diagnosed with metabolic syndrome on routine workup. Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient?

choices.text: Increase in uric acid and insulin
Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol

questions.solution:
Increase in triglycerides and total cholesterol is seen in patients with metabolic syndrome.

Metabolic syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met, which is given by NCEP-ATP III (National Cholesterol Education program and adult treatment panel III). It includes-

  • Central obesity: waist circumference >102 cm (M), >88 cm (F)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia: triglyceride level ≥ 150 mg/dL
  • Low HDL cholesterol: <40 mg/dL and <50 mg/dL for men and women, respectively.
  • Hypertension: blood pressure ≥130 mmHg systolic or ≥ 85 mmHg diastolic.
  • Fasting plasma glucose level ≥100 mg/dL or specific medication or previously diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A male patient presented with complaints of imbalance, numbness of the foot, and muscle weakness. On history taking, he revealed that he has been taking multivitamin tablets more than the prescribed dose for 1 year. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the associated symptoms seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette points towards the diagnosis of vitamin B6 toxicity due to excess intake of vitamin B6 supplements.

The active form of vitamin B6/pyridoxine is pyridoxal phosphate(PLP). PLP acts as a coenzyme for many reactions such as transaminations, decarboxylations, metabolism of sulfur-containing amino acids, heme synthesis, niacin synthesis, and glycogenolysis.

Drugs that decrease pyridoxine levels include isoniazid, cycloserine,oral contraceptives, and alcohol. Deficiency manifestations of vitamin B6 include convulsions, peripheral neuritis, pellagra due to decreased niacin synthesis, and hypochromic microcytic anemia due to inhibition of heme synthesis. Vitamin B6 levels can be measured by erythrocyte transaminase assay.

Excessive intake of food-based sources of pyridoxine doesn’t cause toxicity, the only source of pyridoxine toxicity is from the intake of supratherapeutic dosing of supplements more than 100-200mg/day or iatrogenic. Pyridoxine toxicity manifests as neurological symptoms including numbness, tingling sensation, muscle weakness, and difficulty in ambulation in severe cases.

Other options:

Option A: Intake of vitamin D of more than 10,000 units per day can cause toxicity and it manifests as weakness, polyuria, intense thirst, difficulty in speaking, hypertension, weight loss, and metastatic calcification(calcinosis).

Option C: 

Clinical features of Vitamin C toxicity:

  • Abdominal pain, diarrhoea, nausea
  • Increased prevalence of kidney stones (oxalate)
  • Iron overload (in patients on supplement iron)
  • Hemolysis (G6PD deficiency)

Option D: Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman was diagnosed with a large tumor in the right ovary and histopathology shows it has origin from all three germ layers. Which of the following is the most likely tumor she is having?
questions.solution:
A cyst with all three germ layers is most likely to be a teratoma, also called a dermoid cyst(mature cystic).

Teratomas arise from pluripotent stem cells that differentiate into any of three germ layers forming tissues of all three germ layers. 

A dermoid cyst is the most common germ cell tumor. It is also the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group and in pregnancy. It is bilateral in 10-15% of cases. 

A dermoid cyst is derived from all three germ cell layers, but ectodermal derivatives are most common. Rokitansky’s protuberance is the most common site for the development of malignancy. It is seen as a projection covered by skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth, and bones. Sometimes thyroid tissue can be seen on histopathological examination, known as struma ovarii.

The image below shows a dermoid cyst with Rokitansky protuberance.

questions.text: A primipara is being evaluated for hearing impairment which had worsened during her pregnancy. Rinne’s test is negative in both ears and Weber’s test is lateralized to the right side. On otoscopy, tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry shows a dip in BC at 2000 Hz. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the treatment of choice for otosclerosis is stapedotomy.

Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

Stapedectomy is the excision of the entire stapes (superstructure + footplate) and placing a piston in its place. It is outdated.

Sodium fluoride (NaF) is used in an active case of otosclerosis to hasten maturation.

Note: 

  • Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence stapedotomy is preferred over stapedectomy and is considered the treatment of choice.
  • In the above case since Rinne’s test is negative on both ears, it indicates bilateral conductive deafness. Weber’s test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive loss.

questions.text: A farmer is brought to the hospital 8 hours later, following a snake bite. He complained of headache, blurred vision, tingling sensation around the mouth, dizziness, vertigo, and multiple episodes of vomiting since the bite. He has signs of respiratory depression and a pulse <50. The local wound showed mild swelling and blistering. There are no apparent bleeding manifestations. He was administered 10 vials of antivenom. Which of the following is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a neurotoxic snake bite. Since this patient has already passed 8 hours without any bleeding manifestations, the bite of a hemotoxic snake is unlikely and the better management would be to address his neurotoxic symptoms with the administration of neostigmine with atropine.

The neurotoxic symptoms are reversible with the use of antivenoms or anticholinesterase drugs, such as neostigmine. Atropine is administered to counter the muscarinic side effects of neostigmine. 

Neurotoxic symptoms include: 

  • Headache
  • Blurred vision
  • Perioral paraesthesia (tingling sensation around the mouth)
  • Vomiting
  • Dizziness
  • Vertigo
  • Hyperacusis
  • Gooseflesh
  • Hypersalivation

Respiratory failure is precipitated either by airway obstruction or paralysis of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, at this stage or later. If it progresses to paralysis, it initially presents with ptosis and external ophthalmoplegia, which may appear between a few minutes after the bite or after some hours.

ASV(Anti Snake Venom) is the mainstay of snakebite treatment. Neurotoxicity effects may wear off spontaneously in about a week and are completely reversible in response to antivenom or anticholinesterase. Atropine can be used in the management of venom that acts postsynaptically. Ventilatory support is provided in cases complicated with severe respiratory depression, in the event of failure of other measures of management. 

ASV used in India is effective against:

  • Cobra
  • Common krait
  • Russel viper
  • Saw scaled viper

Measures that can be done in the case of snakebite:

  • Apply firm pressure over the bitten area, which delays the absorption of venom
  • Pressure immobilization is recommended for elapid and sea-snake bites, but not for viper bites as it may cause local necrosis
  • Clean the wound with soap and water, or iodine and cover it with a sterile dressing 
  • Immediately apply a broad firm bandage (Sutherland wrap) on the bitten area and around the limb. As much of the limb should be bandaged as possible. It should be tight enough to occlude the superficial venous and lymphatic return, but not the arterial or deep venous flow. 
  • In bites on the trunk, head, or neck, apply firm pressure over the bitten area
  • Immobilize the limb, as movement can accelerate the spread of venom
  • Make the patient lie on one side in the recovery position so that the airway is clear, in case of vomiting or fainting

Measures contraindicated in the case of snakebite:

  • Suction and incision of the wound
  • Electric shock treatment of wound site
  • Application of tourniquets because they obstruct arterial flow and cause ischemia
  • Ice water immersion of the bitten limb

questions.text: A newborn presented to the NICU with respiratory distress and meconium discharge from the umbilicus. The condition occurs due to the patency of the which structure?
questions.solution:
The presence of meconium discharge at the umbilicus is suggestive of vitelline fistula, which occurs due to patent vitelline duct, which connects the primitive gut to the yolk sac.

The primitive gut is connected to the definitive yolk sac through a narrow stalk-like communication known as the vitellointestinal duct. It is also known as vitelline duct or yolk stalk or omphalomesenteric duct. 

Due to the folding of the embryo in the cephalocaudal and lateral directions, the embryo gets enclosed all around by ectoderm, except in the region through which the vitellointestinal duct passes. In this region, there is a circular aperture, which is now called the umbilical opening. The vitellointestinal duct completely obliterates by the 7th week of development.

Vitelline duct abnormalities:

  • Meckel's diverticulum: In about 2% of the individuals, a portion of the vitelline duct persists an outpouching of the ileum called, Meckel diverticulum. The diverticulum is usually asymptomatic unless it contains heterotopic pancreatic or gastric mucosa, which may lead to bleeding, ulceration, or perforation.
  • Vitelline cyst: In some individuals, both the ends of the vitelline duct transform into fibrous cords. However, the middle portion of the duct forms a large cyst called, enterocystoma, or vitelline cyst. As the fibrous cords run across the peritoneal cavity, it may lead to intestinal obstruction, strangulation, or volvulus.
  • Vitelline fistula: When the vitelline duct remains patent over its entire length, it forms a direct communication between the primitive gut and the umbilicus, a condition called an umbilical fistula or vitelline fistula. The newborn characteristically presents with meconium discharge from the umbilicus.

questions.text:
Identify the correct type of facial nerve palsy in the following patients based on their clinical features:

Patient 1 - Deviation of angle of mouth to left, eyelids completely closed and wrinkling of the forehead. 
Patient 2 - Deviation of angle of mouth to left, the right eyelid remains partially open, and no wrinkling of the forehead.

choices.text: A-Right LMN facial nerve palsy B-Left UMN facial nerve palsy
A-Right  UMN facial nerve palsy B-Right LMN facial nerve palsy
A-Left UMN facial nerve palsy B-Right LMN facial nerve palsy
A-Left LMN facial nerve palsy B-Right UMN facial nerve palsy

questions.solution:
Patient 1 has left UMN facial nerve palsy and patient 2 has right LMN facial nerve palsy.

In an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion, wrinkling on the forehead and eyelid closure remains intact. In this lesion, the contralateral side of the face is affected. The first-order neurons from the left cerebral hemisphere cross over (left to right) at the cortical level and relay in the right facial nerve nucleus in the pons. From here the second-order neurons (right facial nerve) descend and supply the right side of the face. 

Hence, a left UMN lesion causes paralysis of the lower half of the face on the right side. In facial palsy, the angle of the mouth deviates towards the normal side. In this patient, since the mouth deviates towards the left, the right facial nerve is affected. 

In lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions, there is an absence of wrinkling on the forehead and incomplete closure of the eyelid on the ipsilateral side of the face.

Features of facial nerve palsy:

Feature UMN LMN
Side affected Contralateral Ipsilateral
Facial muscles involved Lower Both upper and lower
Forehead wrinkling Present Absent
Emotional incontinence Present Absent
Corneal reflex Normal Absent
Taste Intact Affected
Atrophy of facial muscles Absent Present

questions.text:
A 7-year-old male child presented with an episode of convulsions that had been ongoing for 45 minutes. He has a past medical history of GTCS. What would be the most appropriate management in this case?

GTCS - Generalized tonic–clonic seizure
questions.solution:
This scenario described above is of status epilepticus. The first drug used is Lorazepam to immediately control and stop the seizure, followed by  Levetiracetam once the acute phase is managed.

Status epilepticus refers to continuous seizures or repetitive, discrete seizures with impaired consciousness in the inter-ictal period. For practical purposes, status epilepticus is defined as any one of the following:

  • Continuing seizures >5 minutes or
  • No regaining of consciousness between 2 seizures.

The initial choice of therapy is a benzodiazepine, which includes either of the following:

  • Intravenous lorazepam
  • Intravenous diazepam
  • Intramuscular midazolam- If IV access is not available

If the seizure still continues, we can repeat the above dose once again. If there is no response even after repeat doses, then a single dose of either of the antiepileptics can be given,

  • Intravenous fosphenytoin 
  • Intravenous valproic acid 
  • Intravenous levetiracetam 

If the seizure activity continues for 30 minutes even after administration of two doses of a benzodiazepine and an antiepileptic drug, it is known as refractory status epilepticus. This patient requires endotracheal intubation for ventilatory support. General anaesthesia is induced using continuous infusion of midazolam, propofol, or phenobarbital.

questions.text: You see a child with delayed speech development as part of a health visit at a local school. The otoscopic appearance of the ear is shown below. Hearing loss of 20 dB is detected in audiometric tests. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image suggest a diagnosis of serous otitis media. 

The golden yellow discoloration of the tympanic membrane is caused by the clear watery straw-colored effusion filling the middle ear. Since the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the middle ear quite clearly on otoscopy.

Patients having serous otitis media will have hearing loss that rarely exceeds 40 dB. This deafness can pass unnoticed, and maybe accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests. Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective.

Otoscopic findings in serous otitis media:

  • Fluid level and air bubbles are seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent.
  • In chronic cases, the fluid becomes very sticky. Hence, the name glue ear. 
  • The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex.
  • The mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease who is on inhaled salmeterol therapy presents to the outpatient department with complaints that there is no improvement. Which of the following drugs can be added to his regime?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is already on bronchodilators with inhaled salmeterol. The next step in the management of this patient is to add another bronchodilator like a  muscarinic antagonist that is Ipratropium. 

Treatment of COPD:

  • Smoking cessation
  • Anticholinergic agents- Ipratropium bromide
  • Beta Agonists- Long-acting inhaled β agonists, such as salmeterol or formoterol are commonly used. 
  • Methylxanthines- theophylline produces improvements in expiratory flow rates and vital capacity. 
  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitors - roflumilast is used when FEV1<50%. 
  • Antibiotics- macrolides like azithromycin reduce exacerbations when used over one year
  • N-acetylcysteine has been used in patients with COPD for both its mucolytic and antioxidant properties
  • Oxygen therapy

Non-pharmacologic therapies:

  • Lung volume reduction surgery
  • Lung transplantation

questions.text: An industrial worker was admitted to the hospital after an eye injury sustained while cutting stone with a hammer and iron chisel. A foreign body was suspected to be impacted in his eye. Which of the following is the best investigation for foreign body localization?
questions.solution:
CT scan is the best method for intraocular foreign body (IOFB) localization.

The foreign bodies most likely to penetrate and be retained in the eye are minute chips of iron or steel. While chipping stone with an iron chisel, the chip of the iron chisel is more likely to enter the eye than the stone. A foreign body entering the eye may cause damage by:

  • mechanical effects
  • introduction of infection
  • reacting with the intraocular tissues

Anteroposterior and lateral view X-rays are recommended for locating an IOFB as most foreign bodies are radio-opaque. Ultrasonographic localization can tell the position of even non-radiopaque foreign bodies. CT scan is the best method of IOFB localization.

MRI is contraindicated for metallic IOFB.MRI can be detrimental for a patient with a history of an intraocular foreign body (IOFB) after cutting stone with a hammer and chisel. It can cause further damage by producing movements of the foreign body if it is magnetic. The use of MRI is contraindicated for metallic (iron) foreign bodies and is not recommended as a screening procedure.

Management: A foreign body should always be removed unless:

  • it is inert and probably sterile
  • little damage has been done to vision 
  • the process of removal will destroy sight

 

Siderosis bulbi refers to the ocular degenerative changes produced by an iron foreign body. It usually occurs 2 months to 2 years after the injury. This condition is due to the electrolytic dissociation of the metal by an intrinsic resting current in the eye which disseminates the metal, combining it with cellular proteins and cause atrophy.

Clinical features:

  • Iris: first stained greenish and later turns reddish-brown, causing heterochromia iridis.
  • Pupil: iron deposition in sphincter leads to mydriasis.
  • Lens: iron deposition in a radial fashion on the anterior capsule of the lens, leading to anterior capsular cataract.
  • Retina: pigmentary retinopathy; followed by atrophy of the retina and retinal pigmentary epithelium.
  • Secondary open-angle Glaucoma: due to damage to the trabecular meshwork.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with frequent headaches. Investigation reveals raised intracranial pressure and the presence of a dural-based tumor. Which of the following histological findings correlate with the diagnosis?

choices.text: Psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of a dural-based tumor presenting with headaches and raised intracranial pressure is most likely a meningioma and they have psammoma bodies with whorling of tumor cells on histopathological examination.

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumors of adults, usually attached to the dura, that arise from the meningothelial cells of the arachnoid.

  • Meningiomas may be found along any of the external surfaces of the brain as well as within the ventricular system, where they arise from the stromal arachnoid cells of the choroid plexus.
  • Prior radiation therapy to the head and neck, typically is a risk factor.
  • The most common cytogenetic abnormality is the loss of chromosome 22, especially the long arm (22q).
  • Meningiomas are a common lesion in the setting of NF2 (multiple sites, especially in association with acoustic neuromas or glial tumors.
  • The surface of the mass is usually encapsulated.
  • They may also grow en plaque, in which the tumor spreads in a sheetlike fashion along the surface of the dura. This form is commonly associated with hyperostotic reactive changes in the adjacent bone.
  • The lesions may contain numerous calcified psammoma bodies.

Psammoma bodies are shown below:

Histological subtypes:

  • WHO Grade I – Menigothelial, fibroblastic, transitional, psammomatous, secretory, microcystic
  • WHO Grade II- Clear cell, choroid, atypical
  • Grade III – Papillary, rhabdoid, anaplastic
  • Atypical meningiomas (WHO grade II/IV) - a higher rate of recurrence and more aggressive local growth
  • Anaplastic (malignant) meningioma (WHO grade III/IV) - highly aggressive tumor with the appearance of a high-grade sarcoma
  • Immunoreactive for epithelial membrane antigen
  • Keratin is restricted to lesions with the secretory pattern, and these tumors are also positive for carcinoembryonic antigen
  • Moderate (3: 2) female predominance, usually solitary, but when present at multiple sites, the possibility of neurofibromatosis type 2 should be considered.
  • Meningiomas often express progesterone receptors and may grow more rapidly during pregnancy.

Option A: Fried egg appearance of cells refers to cells with clear cytoplasm and a nucleus with a prominent nucleolus. Fried egg appearance in pathology are:

  • Oligodendroglioma on histopathology
  • Hairy cell leukemia on bone marrow biopsy
  • Seminoma/Dysgerminoma on light microscopy
  • Mycoplasma pneumonia fried egg colonies on Eaton agar

Option B: Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes with arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen can be seen in retinoblastoma.

Option D: In medulloblastoma, tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neurophil can be seen.

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions will shift the Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve to the left?
questions.solution:
An increase in the pH (alkalosis), shifts the O2-hemoglobin dissociation curve, to the left.

Oxygen-Hb dissociation curve (OHDC)

  • This is a plot of the partial pressure of O2 and the % saturation of Hb with O2.
  • It is normally sigmoid in shape.
  • If OHDC is shifted to the right, it means that the affinity of Hb for O2 has become less (which favors O2 delivery) i.e. Higher the P50. (R - Right shift Releases oxygen)

Shift to the right is caused by: (Conditions with an increased requirement of O2 - metabolically active tissues)

  • Hypoxia and Hypercarbia - Metabolically active tissues utilize O2 and tissues produce CO2
  • ↓ pH - Secondary to increased CO2 production
  • ↑ in temperature, heat 
  • ↑ in 2,3-DPG - increased anaerobic glycolysis
  • Growth hormone, thyroid hormone, androgen - by increasing 2,3 DPG
  • Sickle cell anemia - reduced affinity for O2

Shift to the left is caused by:

  • ↑ pH (alkalosis)
  • ↓ PCO2
  • ↓ 2,3-DPG
  • ↓ Temperature 
  • HbF
  • Carboxyhemoglobin

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, vomiting, and watery diarrhea. He gives a history of having consumed shellfish and raw seafood a day before. The causative agent showed the Kanagawa phenomenon on Wagatsuma agar.  What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Kanagawa Phenomenon is shown by Vibrio parahaemolyticus. The Kanagawa phenomenon is hemolysis on wagatsuma agar.

On Wagatsuma agar (High salt blood agar), pathogenic strains of V. parahaemolyticus are hemolytic, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

V. parahaemolyticus causes food poisoning due to the consumption of contaminated seafood, after an incubation period of 12–24 hours. The common sources of infection are raw seafood like mollusks and crustaceans. No enterotoxin like cholera toxin has been identified, it causes enteritis by invasion of the intestinal epithelium.

Clinically, patients present with nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, fever, and watery or bloody diarrhea. Fecal leukocytes are often seen in stool samples. Enteritis subsides spontaneously in 1–3 days with no specific treatment. Adequate hydration and electrolyte balance should be restored.

V. parahaemolyticus is a capsulated bacterium. It shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. It is characterized by peritrichous flagella on solid media and polar flagella on liquid media and it gives a positive string test.

Pathogenic strains of V. parahemolyticus are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar, while non-pathogenic strains are non-hemolytic. This is called the Kanagawa phenomenon and is due to a heat-stable hemolysin.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with a fever persisting for 3 weeks. He gives a history of prosthetic valve implantation 6 months before.
