questions.text: Which of the following develops from the dorsal mesogastrium?
questions.solution:
The spleen develops from the mesoderm in the dorsal mesogastrium.

The mesenchymal cells in the dorsal mesogastrium form small lobular masses of splenic tissue called spleniculi. Later, these lobules fuse to form a single mass of spleen. The capsule, septa, and connective tissue framework, including reticular fibers, develop from mesoderm. The mesenchymal cells also differentiate into lymphoblasts and other blood-forming cells.

When the spleen develops, the dorsal mesogastrium gets divided into an anterior segment called gastrosplenic ligament that extends from the spleen to stomach, and a posterior part called the lienorenal ligament that extends from the spleen to the left kidney.

questions.text: In a given population, 4050 births were recorded over a period of 1 year. Among these, 50 were stillbirths, 50 died in the 1st week of life and 150 died within 8-28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate of this population?
questions.solution:
The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) of the given population is 50 per 1000 live births.

Neonatal mortality rate = No. of deaths of neonates < 28 days within a year x 1000 / Total live births in the same year

In this population, there were 4000 live births (no. of total births - no. of stillbirths).

NMR = (50+150) x 1000/4000 = 100/2 = 50

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with ear wax and was subjected to syringing to remove the wax. She developed a syncopal episode while doing the procedure when the tip of the syringe touched the ear canal. Which of the nerves is responsible for this episode of syncope?
questions.solution:
The posterior wall of the external auditory canal is supplied by the auricular branch of the Vagus (Arnold's nerve). When this nerve is stimulated, a vasovagal response is initiated which results in the syncopal episode. 

When the vagus nerve is stimulated, a parasympathetic response occurs leading to braycardia and decreased blood flow into the brain which causes syncope.

Nerve supply of External auditory canal:

  • Anterior wall and roof- the auriculotemporal branch of mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (CN V3)
  • Posterior wall and floor - the auricular branch of Vagus (Arnold's nerve). Cough response while cleaning the ear canal is mediated by the vagus which also supplies the larynx.
  • Posterior wall also receives sensory supply by the facial nerve (CN VII)

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of hemolytic anemia?

choices.text: All of the options given below

questions.solution:
Serum haptoglobin levels are decreased in hemolytic anemias. In intravascular hemolysis, free hemoglobin released from lysed red cells is promptly bound by haptoglobin, producing a complex that is rapidly cleared by mononuclear phagocytes. In cases of extravascular hemolysis, some hemoglobin inevitably escapes from phagocytes and leads to variable decreases in plasma haptoglobin.

Hemolytic anemias are characterized by a shortened red cell life span of less than the normal 120 days. This leads to elevated erythropoietin levels and a compensatory increase in erythropoiesis which is seen as prominent reticulocytosis (OptionC) in the peripheral blood. In addition, there is an accumulation of hemoglobin degradation products produced due to hemolysis. 

 

Types of hemolysis based on location:

  • Intravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs mainly within the blood vessels
  • Extravascular hemolysis - hemolysis that occurs via macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system in the spleen, liver, bone marrow, and lymph nodes

Features of intravascular hemolysis are:

  • Decreased haptoglobin
  • Increased lactate dehydrogenase 
  • Hemoglobinemia
  • Hemoglobinuria
  • Hemosiderinuria
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • Methemoglobinuria
  • Indirect hyperbilirubinemia

Features of extravascular hemolysis are:

  • Anemia
  • Splenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Variable decreases in plasma haptoglobin

questions.text: In which type of poisoning will there be increased secretion along with diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Increased secretion along with diarrhea can be seen in ketamine poisoning.

Ketamine is a phencyclidine derivative that inhibits NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptors resulting in a decrease in excitatory stimulation by glutamate in the brain. It is a strong analgesic and amnestic agent. 

Uses:

  • Ketamine is the intravenous agent of choice for patients with shock, low cardiac output states, and reactive airway diseases.
  • It is also used in patients with congenital heart diseases, especially with right-to-left shunts
  • Perioperative analgesia

Other adverse effects:

  • Hallucination is the most common side effect of ketamine.
  • Emergence reaction (vivid dreaming, illusion, etc)
  • Increased salivation, nausea, vomiting
  • Increases brain oxygen consumption and metabolic rate leading to increased intracranial tension.

Other options:

Cannabis: Large doses of cannabis causes nausea, anxiety, confusion, hallucinations and delusions. This is followed by giddiness, confusion, drowsiness and dilated pupils. 

Cocaine: Acute intoxication mainly causes euphoria, hypervigilance, agitation, tactile hallucination, and finally respiratory failure or cardiac arrest.

Crack: This is obtained by heating the cocaine with sodium bicarbonate to yield a hard white mass. This material gives off a cracking sound when smoked and hence the name.

questions.text:
Which of these drugs stimulates PPAR- alpha?

PPAR alpha-Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha
questions.solution:
Gemfibrozil is a fibrate that stimulates PPAR (Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor) alpha.

Fibrates bind to PPAR alpha and cause stimulation of lipoprotein lipase enzyme. Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) is a key enzyme in the degradation of VLDL. Increased LPL synthesis enhances the clearance of triglyceride-rich lipoproteins. Additionally, fibrates also stimulate fatty acid oxidation and reduce the expression of apo C-III (inhibitor of lipolysis).

Gemfibrozil is a first line drug for patients with markedly raised triglyceride levels. Episodes of acute pancreatitis are prevented in patients with chylomicronaemia and severe hypertriglyceridaemia. It is most effective in type III hyperlipoproteinaemia.

Other options:

Option B: Ezetimibe is a novel drug that acts by inhibiting intestinal absorption of dietary as well as biliary cholesterol by interfering with a specific cholesterol transporter protein in the intestinal mucosa.

Option C: Colestipol are bile acid sequestrants which are basic ion exchange resins supplied in the chloride form. They have been shown to retard atherosclerosis and coronary events.

Opttion D: Simvastatin competitively inhibit conversion of 3-Hydroxy-3-methyl glutaryl coenzyme A (HMG-CoA) to mavalonate by the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase. This is the rate limiting step in the cholesterol synthesis.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain and diarrhea.  On further evaluation, the patient was found to have cutaneous flushing, extensive wheeze, and tricuspid insufficiency. Contrast enhanced-MRI revealed the presence of endocardial fibrosis. Which of the following substances will be excreted excessively in this patient?
questions.solution:
5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) will be excreted excessively in the above given clinical scenario, as this is a case of carcinoid syndrome.

Carcinoid syndrome is due to excessive production of serotonin, a specialized product of tryptophan metabolism. It is then metabolized and excreted in urine as 5-HIAA. It is characterized by cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhoea. 

Note:

5-HIAA testing is a 24-hour urine test that is specific to carcinoid tumours. This test is the most common biochemical test for carcinoid tumours associated with carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency department after he fell into a manhole and injured his perineum. He was unable to pass urine and blood was seen at the tip of the urethra. A diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was made.  Where do you least expect the urine to get collected in this case?
questions.solution:
In bulbar urethral injury, the medial portion of the thigh is the least likely site for the collection of urine.

The rupture of the urethra below the urogenital diaphragm will result in extravasation of urine into the superficial perineal pouch, penis and scrotum in males and labia majora in females, and the anterior abdominal wall.

The superficial fascia of the abdomen is divided below the umbilicus into a superficial fatty layer (fascia of Camper) and a deep membranous layer (fascia of Scarpa). Scarpa's fascia is continuous with the membranous layer of the superficial perineal fascia (Colles' fascia). 

Colles' fascia is attached to fascia lata (the deep fascia of the thigh) along the Holden's line that extends from the pubic tubercle laterally for 8 cm. Extravasated fluid cannot pass into the medial thigh below Holden's line due to the firm attachment of Colles' fascia to the fascia lata.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding single exposure point source epidemic ?

choices.text: Has more than one incubation period
Occurs due to prolonged exposure to an agent

questions.solution:
The true statement regarding single exposure point source epidemic is that it is explosive in nature.

Single exposure point source epidemics occur due to a brief and simultaneous exposure to an agent. It has the following characteristics:

  • It has a single peak with no secondary waves.
  • The epidemic tends to be explosive, there is a clustering of cases within a narrow interval of time.
  • The epidemic curve has a sharp, rapid rise and fall as all cases are clustered within one incubation period.

The exposure can be an infectious agent or contaminant in the environment (air, water, food, soil) by industrial chemicals or pollutants. Examples are food poisoning and the Bhopal gas tragedy in India due to methyl isocyanate.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient who was using presbyopic glasses for the past few years is now able to comfortably read the newspaper without the glasses. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of improvement in near vision of a presbyopic patient is termed the second sight phenomenon. This is seen due to index myopia caused by the formation of nuclear cataracts.

Presbyopia, also known as the eyesight of old age, is a condition of physiological insufficiency of accommodation leading to a progressive fall in near vision. The treatment of presbyopia is the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

In nuclear cataracts, nuclear sclerosis occurs leading to an increase in refractive index. This leads to progressive myopia known as index myopia. When a presbyopic patient develops a nuclear cataract, this increase in the refractive index of the lens compensates for the physiological insufficiency of accommodation that the patient has.

Thus, a patient with presbyopia may be able to read again, without the aid of spectacles due to this improvement in near vision, termed second sight. At the same time, this increased refractive index causes a deterioration in far vision.

Option B: Index hypermetropia occurs in cortical cataracts and sclerosis that lead to a decrease in the refractive index of the lens in old age. In such patients, there will be worsening of the near vision which does not align with the history of a presbyopic being able to read with his glasses.

Option C: Presbyopia occurs due to a decrease in the accommodative power of the crystalline lens with increasing age, and thus does not regress spontaneously. It can however be easily corrected with the prescription of appropriate convex glasses for near work.

questions.text: How often should health check-ups be conducted for children aged 9-18 years under the RBSK program?
questions.solution:
According to the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) program, health check-ups for children aged 9-18 years should occur semi-annually.

This frequency allows healthcare providers to comprehensively assess various aspects of the child's health, including physical, mental, and emotional well-being. Semi-annual check-ups enable early detection of any emerging health issues, facilitate timely interventions, and ensure continuity of care. This proactive approach helps promote overall health and contributes to improved health outcomes among children. 

Option (a): Monthly health check-ups may be overly frequent and impractical, potentially burdening healthcare resources unnecessarily.

Option (c): Quarterly assessments may not be necessary for children in this age group unless specific health concerns arise. Semi-annual check-ups strike a balance between monitoring and avoiding excessive medicalization.

Option (d): Annual check-ups may not suffice to monitor the dynamic health needs of children aged 9-18 years adequately.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is brought to the ER due to a suspected stroke. The patient has difficulty forming words but can make noises and give expressions as if he understands the questions asked. Which type of aphasia is most likely present in the patient?

Option D: Conduction aphasia is seen in lesions of the arcuate fasciculus, the bundle of nerve fibres connecting the Wernicke and Broca's areas. Repetition of words is impaired and paraphasias are observed, though not as much as in Wernicke aphasia.

questions.text: A newly married female patient who is 22 weeks pregnant came in for MTP on the grounds of contraceptive failure. MTP can be performed after?
questions.solution:
The upper limit of MTP is 20 weeks in case of contraception failure.

Upper limit of MTP:

  • Up to 24 weeks of gestation in victims of rape and incest, fetal anomalies, or congenital malformations
  • Up to 20 weeks in case of contraception failure (any female with her partner)
  • At any gestational age for substantial fetal anomalies decided by the medical board

Opinion of doctors:

  • Till 20 weeks - 1 doctor's opinion
  • 20 to 24 weeks - 2 doctors' opinion
  • For substantial fetal anomalies - approval from the medical board consisting of an obstetrician, paediatrician, radiologist and a person appointed by the state.

Consent:

Only the patient/mother's consent is required for MTP; her partner's consent is not required. Consent of parent/guardian is needed if the age of the patient is <18 years or if the patient is mentally ill.

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint be lodged with the police.

The consent of the woman is required for conducting an abortion. The written consent of the guardian is required if the woman is minor or mentally ill. Consent of the husband or partner is not necessary. 

If the woman is not willing, abortion cannot be performed at the request of the husband alone. The woman need not produce proof of her age. It is enough for the woman to say that she was raped, and it is not necessary that a complaint was lodged with the police.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with hypertension presents at the hospital. His blood pressure upon examination is 150/90, and he is afebrile. Further evaluation reveals normal serum renin levels, leading to a diagnosis of Conn's syndrome. All of the following conditions would be seen in Conn's syndrome except?
questions.solution:
Conn's syndrome presents with Metabolic alkalosis.

Patients with Conn's syndrome have primary hyperaldosteronism which results in a modest increase in plasma sodium, usually less than 4-6 mEq/L over the normal range, hypokalemia (due to increased K+excretion), hypertension (due to slight increase in ECF volume), metabolic alkalosis because increased hydrogen ions are secreted in the urine.

Excess secretion of aldosterone causes only a modest increase in plasma sodium. When sodium gets reabsorbed, water also accompanies it, resulting in plasma sodium remaining fairly normal.

Primary hyperaldosteronism is due to autonomous overproduction of aldosterone with resultant suppression of RAAS. It can occur due to adrenal hyperplasia, adenoma, or carcinoma. It is associated with the following features:

  • Hypertension (most common)
  • Hypokalemia
  • Metabolic alkalosis
  • Polyuria (due to ANP)
  • Polydipsia (due to polyuria)
  • Muscle weakness

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, blood-coloured nasal discharge. On examination, there is septal perforation. Biopsy from the nose shows necrosis and non-caseating granuloma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing septal perforation, bloody nasal discharge with non caseating granuloma is suggestive of Wegener's granulomatosis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis).

Wegener's granulomatosis is a systemic disorder which primarily involve the upper airways, lungs, kidneys, and the skin

Involvement of the upper respiratory tract in granulomatosis with polyangiitis manifests as:

  • Paranasal sinusitis, serous otitis media
  • Nasal ulcers, purulent or bloody nasal discharge
  • Nasal perforation leading to the destruction of septum and saddle nose deformity
  • Subglottic tracheal stenosis

General symptoms like fatigue night sweats, and arthralgia is also seen. Once lung involvement happens, cough and hemoptysis begins. Renal involvement is late and is detected as RBC and casts in urine.

questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition shown in the graph.
questions.solution:
The above graph is called a 'Lineweaver-Burk plot' or 'double reciprocal' plot and it represents noncompetitive inhibition.

Non-competitive inhibition: When the substrate and the inhibitor are chemically not similar and have different shapes, the inhibitor binds away from the active site, i.e., at the allosteric site. This type of inhibition is known as non-competitive inhibition.

In non-competitive inhibition,

  • Vmax decreases.(1/Vmax increases)
  • Km remains constant.

In a Lineweaver-Burk Plot, the addition of a non-competitive inhibitor causes plots with the same x-intercept (Km is unaffected) but different slopes and y-intercepts.

Competitive inhibition - Here, the inhibitor is a structural analog of the substrate. Inhibitor molecules are competing with the normal substrate molecules for binding to the active site of the enzyme. Here Vmax is unchanged (same y-intercept), and Km is increased (− 1/Km moves closer to zero from a negative value).

Uncompetitive inhibition  - Here, the inhibitor does not have any affinity for the free enzyme. The inhibitor binds to the enzyme-substrate complex, but not to the free enzyme. Here, both Vmax and Km are decreased.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction. On examination, an irregular mass was visualized in the nasal cavity.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis is antrochoanal polyp.

Antrochoanal polyp is a type of non-neoplastic nasal polypoidal masses of edematous nasal or sinus mucosa. It arises from the mucosa of the maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it, and grows in the choana and nasal cavity. It is usually single and unilateral which are more commonly seen in children and young adults. 

It has 3 parts namely

  • Thin antral stalk,
  • Round and globular choanal part, and
  • Flat nasal part.

The clinical features include unilateral nasal obstruction, mucoid nasal discharge, and a hyponasal voice.

A large polyp may protrude from the nasal cavity and may appear pink and congested. It is soft and can be moved with a probe.Anterior rhinoscopy may miss it when it starts to grow posteriorly. Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana and hanging down behind the soft palate.

Diagnosis is made by radiograph of the paranasal sinuses reveals opacity of the involved antrum. Non-contrast CT scan reveals the extent of the polyp. Endoscopic examination reveals the antrochoanal polyp hidden posteriorly in the nasal cavity.

Endoscopic sinus surgery is the treatment of choice. Recurrence is uncommon after the complete removal of the polyp.

Option A thornwaldt cyst is the persistence of pouch of lushka and is located at the midline on the posterior nasopharyngeal wall. It rarely presents as a mass protruding in the nasal cavity

Option B hypertrophic rhinitis is the inflammation and thickening of nasal mucose, submucosa, glands and periosteum. It doesn't present as a mass lesion

Option C deviated nasal septum presents with nasal obstruction, but no mass lesion

  • Usually affects children
  • Site of origin: Mucosa of the maxillary antrum

    • Unilateral nasal obstruction which becomes bilateral when it grows posteriorly and obstructs opposite choana
    • Mucoid nasal discharge
    • Hyponasal voice

    • Posterior rhinoscopy: Globular mass filling the choana or nasopharynx
  • Investigation of choice: Nasal endoscopy. Shows nasal polyps that are pale, gelatinous and pedunculated

questions.text: Which of the following is not a function of glucagon?
questions.solution:
Glycolysis is not a function of glucagon but is a function of insulin. 

Role of insulin and glucagon:

When blood glucose falls during fasting, there is increased secretion of glucagon and decreased release of insulin.

  2. It favors the synthesis of glucose-6-phosphatase which converts glucose-6-phosphate to glucose. The resulting glucose is used by red blood cells (lack mitochondria) and the brain as they are largely dependent on glucose in the fasting state.
  3. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase and fructose-1, 6-bisphosphatase are induced, leading to increased gluconeogenesis.

A 65-year-old male, with a known case of coronary artery disease, presented for a general check-up. On examination, vital signs are normal. He has notable long limbs. Blood glucose concentration is 100 mg/dL and homocysteine concentration is 20 μmol/L. Serum lipid levels are normal. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?

Normal homocysteine concentration in blood = 5-15 μmol/L.
questions.solution:
This patient with long limbs, coronary artery disease and elevated homocysteine concentration most likely has homocystinuria, and the enzyme deficiency in this condition is cystathionine β synthase.

Homocystinuria is most commonly caused by a defect in the cystathionine β synthase enzyme leading to the accumulation of homocysteine in urine and blood. They are generally normal at birth and the first sign is subluxation of the lens (ectopia lentis) seen after 3 years of age.

Manifestations of homocystinuria:

  • Ectopia lentis.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly.

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic lab findings.

Other Options:

  • Deficiency of homogentisate oxidase is associated with alkaptonuria.

  • Deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRTase) is responsible for Lesch-Nyhan syndrome.

questions.text: Fast vibration sense is mediated by ______.
questions.solution:
Fast vibration sense is mediated by Pacinian corpuscles. 

Pacinian corpuscles are the largest cutaneous mechanoreceptors. They are present in the dermis of glabrous and hairy skin. They are composed of a nerve ending that is encapsulated by concentric layers of connective tissue, giving them an onion-like appearance. The sensory nerves from cutaneous mechanoreceptors are myelinated Aα and Aβ fibers. These receptors respond to fast vibration and deep pressure and adapt very rapidly

Option A: Merkel's disc responsible for sensing sustained touch and pressure

Option B: Meissner's corpuscles respond to texture and slow vibration. They are present in dermal papillae and are used in 2-point discrimination.

questions.text: A boy, upon disturbing a bee hive, received several stings. After a few minutes, he developed symptoms of shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. This is an example of ______.
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following a bee sting is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or type 1 hypersensitivity. Injurious immune reactions are called hypersensitivity reactions.

Immediate (type I) hypersensitivity:

  • These are also called allergic reactions or allergies.
  • They are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals
  • IgE coats mast cells by binding to Fcεg receptors; reexposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI, activation of mast cells, and release of mediators.
  • The principal mediators are histamine, proteases, and other granule contents; prostaglandins and leukotrienes; as well as cytokines.
  • The mediators are responsible for the immediate vascular and smooth muscle reactions and the late-phase reaction (inflammation).
  • The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis.
  • It occurs in two phases: immediate phase and late phase.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old male presented with yellowish discoloration of his skin and sclera. He is otherwise normal. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. He also gives a history of similar episodes in the past following any illness. Lab values are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 2.4 mg/dL
Unconjugated bilirubin: 2.1mg/dL
Conjugated bilirubin: 0.3mg/dL
Serum AST and ALT: Normal
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette points toward the diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

This patient's mild jaundice seen only during a period of stress along with an increase in unconjugated bilirubin and normal AST, and ALT levels strongly point towards a diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Gilbert syndrome is a benign, familial disorder inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern characterized by mild intermittent jaundice usually seen during stress, illnesses, or any other precipitating factors. There is no hemolysis or underlying liver disease. The condition is recognized to arise from a mutation in the promoter region of the UGT1A1 gene, which results in mildly decreased UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production. UDP-Glucoronyltransferase is required for the conjugation of bilirubin.

Precipitating factors in Gilbert syndrome:

  • Dehydration
  • Fasting
  • Menstrual periods
  • Illness
  • Vigorous exercise.

Other options:

Option A: Dubin-Johnson syndrome is a benign autosomal recessive disease that is characterized by chronic conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and conspicuous brown-black melanin-like pigment deposition in the liver. The disease is caused due to mutation in multidrug resistance protein 2 (MRP-2) in hepatocytes, which is required for the transport of non-bile salt organic anions at the canalicular membranes. Liver biopsy shows characteristic deposition of black-colored pigment.

Option B: Crigler-Najjar syndrome is of two types with type 1 having absent/trace UDP-Glucoronyltransferase production and type 2 having <10% of the normal enzyme activity. Hence, type 1 is far more severe and leads to kernicterus and neurological damage in babies. Type 2 may also lead to kernicterus occasionally. Unconjugated bilirubin is elevated. Isolated unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia in a 20-year-old male is less likely to be due to Criggler Najar type 1 syndrome. It is because patients usually die in infancy or early childhood despite the best treatment.

Option D: Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with a milder presentation. Increased conjugated bilirubin levels. Liver biopsy does not show black colored liver

questions.solution:
Cleft lip is due to failure of fusion between the medial nasal prominence and maxillary prominence.

Various defects of fusion of prominences in the face region are as follows:

There is also associated underdevelopment of the part of the maxilla that bears the incisors.
  • Median (midline) cleft lip is a rare defect occurring due to failure of fusion of the two medial nasal prominences in the midline.
  • Oblique facial cleft is caused by the failure of the maxillary prominence to fuse with the lateral nasal prominence along the line of the nasolacrimal groove. The nasolacrimal duct is exposed to the surface in these cases.

questions.text: Which of the following combination of cylindrical lenses can be used to treat with-the-rule astigmatism?
questions.solution:
- 3.00 DC x 180, + 1.00 DC x 90 can be used to correct with-the-rule astigmatism.

In with-the-rule astigmatism, the vertical meridian is steeper than the horizontal meridian. Hence, to make up for this, we need a combination of cylindrical lenses with relatively greater power in the horizontal meridian than the vertical meridian.

Before considering the options, also remember that a cylinder aligned along the horizontal meridian (180 axis) has action in the vertical meridian and vice versa.

In option A, the cylinder acting along the horizontal meridian (- 3.00 DC x 90) has lesser power than the one acting along the vertical meridian (+ 5.00 DC x 180). This is also the case with options B and C.  

Only option D has a cylinder with greater power along the horizontal meridian ( +1.00 DC x 90) compared to the vertical meridian (- 3.00 DC x 180). Hence, option D is the answer.

 Alternative method:

This method involves the use of the optical cross technique

STEP 1:

  • Frame the optical cross with the given powers in their respective meridians.
  • While framing the optical cross, the power which is given in 180 needs to marked in 90 and vice versa.

For example, option A has + 5.00 DC x 180, - 3.00 DC x 90 which means the eye gets a correction of + 5.00 in vertical meridian (i.e in 90 degree) and correction of - 3.00 in horizontal meridian (i.e in 180 degree). Keeping this in mind, if one frames the optical crosses for the given options, the end image would be as given below  

 

 STEP 2:

Now we need to interpret the optical crosses to find which meridian is steeper with certain hints.

  • If the power in one axis is ‘+’ and the power in other axis is ‘-’, then the axis with ‘-’ power is steeper.
  • If powers in both the axis are ‘-’, then the higher number of the two will be steeper.
  • If powers in both the axis are ‘+’, then the lower number of the two will be steeper.

STEP 3:

Applying these hints to the options will give option D as with-the-rule astigmatism.

Postural instability along with bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor are cardinal features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of intense itching, photophobia, and ropy discharge from his eyes. Moreover, on examination the following finding is present. What is the most probable diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above image depicts a cobblestone appearance, and also the presence of ropy discharge points towards the diagnosis of vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) or spring catarrh.

VKC is bilateral allergic conjunctivitis that is common in children above the age of 5 years and in warm dry climates such as the Mediterranean, sub-Saharan Africa, and the Middle East.

It is IgE and cell-mediated inflammation of the conjunctiva. It results in the following findings:

Palpebral disease

  • Cobblestone papillae: Macropapillae (<1 mm) have a flat-topped polygonal appearance reminiscent of cobblestones
  • Associated with ropy discharge
  • Maxwell–Lyon sign: pseudomembrane formation of the upper lid when everted and exposed to heat 

Limbal disease

  • Horner-Trantas dots which are limbal conjunctival papillae

Keratopathy

  • Superior punctate epithelial erosions
  • Shield ulcers, which may develop when the exposed Bowman membrane becomes coated with mucus and calcium phosphate, leading to inadequate wetting and delayed re-epithelialization.
  • Pseudogerentexon resembling arcus senilus. It has a cupid's bow outline

Treatment of VKC includes allergen avoidance, antihistaminics, steroids, and immunomodulators both topical and systemic depending on the severity of the disease.

Other options:

  • Trachoma is a form of chronic infective conjunctivitis and is one of the leading causes of blindness. It has an ‘active’ inflammatory stage and a ‘cicatricial’ chronic stage. The active inflammatory stage is more prevalent in children and presents with nonspecific symptoms of ocular irritation, foreign body sensation, and discharge (often mild symptoms).
  • Phlyctenular conjunctivitis is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction due to endogenous allergens like Staphylococcus aureus (most common) and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Xerophthalmia is a term used to cover all ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

questions.text: Which among the following culture media is used in the identification of Salmonella?
questions.solution:

Salmonella typhi reduces sulphite to sulphide in the presence of glucose and produces jet black colonies with a metallic sheen due to the production of H2S on Wilson and Blair bismuth sulphite medium. It is an example of indicator media. It is also a selective media because inhibiting substances are added to inhibit the growth of unwanted bacteria.

On the Wilson-Blair medium, S. paratyphi A produces green colonies due to the absence of H2S production.

On Deoxycholate citrate media and XLD (xylose lysine deoxycholate), colonies show blackheads due to H2S production.

Other options:

Option 2) BCYE medium (Buffered charcoal yeast extract agar) is used to culture Legionella.

questions.text: A young patient sustained a head injury following a road traffic accident. His family members complain that his behavior has changed following the incident. He is extremely curious and  tries touching everything. He forgets everything rapidly, and he tries to keep everything in his mouth. He even tried to eat the plates. They have also noticed him squeezing his genitals. Which of the following structures is most likely to be damaged in this patient?

choices.text: Gray matter around aqueduct of Sylvius

questions.solution:
Increased curiosity, hyperorality, memory loss, and increased sex drive are the features of Kluver Bucy syndrome. This occurs due to the damage to the amygdala.

Features of Kluver Bucy syndrome are

  • Fearlessness
  • Increased curiosity
  • Memory loss
  • Patient tries to keep everything in mouth, even the solid objects which are not meant for eating
  • Increased sex drive

Functions of amygdala

It receives neuronal signals from the neocortex of the temporal, parietal, and occipital lobes, especially from the auditory and visual association areas. It transmits signals to the same cortical areas, thalamus, hypothalamus, and hippocampus. Stimulation of the amygdala leads to alterations in arterial pressure, heart rate, gastrointestinal motility, piloerection, and abnormal tonic circling and clinic movements. It also has role in olfaction.

Other options:

Option A- Gray matter around the aqueduct of Sylvius is the punishment center. Stimulation of punishment centers leads to the inhibition of reward and pleasure centers completely. Punishment and fear will be more prominent than pleasure and reward.

Option C- Lateral nuclei of hypothalamus is the reward center. Stimulation of this area gives a sense of reward

Option D- Damage to the anterior cingulate gyri releases the rage centers of septum and hypothalamus from the prefrontal inhibitory influence. Therefore the patient becomes very aggressive.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complete anopia in the right eye. The lesion would be present in which specific anatomical structure?
questions.solution:
The most likely site of the lesion causing unilateral complete anopia in the right eye is (c) Right optic nerve. This suggests that there is a problem affecting the visual information from the right eye before the optic chiasma.

Unilateral complete anopia refers to complete blindness in one eye. To determine the location of the lesion, we need to understand the visual pathway:

Right optic radiation: The optic radiation transmits visual information from the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN) to the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Lesions in the optic radiation typically lead to homonymous visual field defects (loss of vision on the same side in both eyes). Since the patient presents with unilateral anopia in the right eye, the optic radiation is less likely to be the site of the lesion.

Optic chiasma: The optic chiasma is where the optic nerves partially cross. Lesions at the optic chiasma often result in bitemporal hemianopia, affecting the temporal visual fields of both eyes. Given that the patient's symptoms are unilateral, the optic chiasma is less likely to be the site of the lesion.

Right optic nerve: The optic nerve carries visual information from the eye to the optic chiasma. A lesion in the right optic nerve would lead to unilateral blindness (anopia) in the right eye, making it a likely site of the lesion in this case.

Right optic tract: The optic tract carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the visual cortex. Lesions in the optic tract could lead to homonymous visual field defects. Since the patient's anopia is unilateral, the right optic tract is less likely to be the site of the lesion.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: The process in the oxidation pond is ________________

choices.text: Aerobic during day, anaerobic during night
Anaerobic during day, aerobic during night

questions.solution:
The process in the oxidation ponds is aerobic during day, and anaerobic during night.

An oxidation pond is a method of sewage disposal that is used to treat both sewage and industrial waste. It is an open, shallow pool of around 1 – 1.5m depth with an inlet and outlet. It requires algae, certain types of saprophytic bacteria and sunlight.

The organic matter is oxidized by bacteria into carbon dioxide, ammonia and water. Algae grow by utilising these with the help of sunlight creating a balance. The oxidation ponds are predominantly aerobic during sunshine hours and some hours of the night. In the remaining hours of the night, the bottom layers are generally anaerobic. The effluent formed can be used for land irrigation or can be forwarded for further treatment.

questions.text: A newborn baby is brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing Direct laryngoscopy, you notice the following findings.  Which of the following stridor is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the laryngoscopy image showing omega-shaped epiglottis is suggestive of laryngomalacia. Inspiratory stridor is seen in laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration. This results in inspiratory stridor, a feature typical of laryngomalacia.

It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor is increased on crying but improves (decreases) in the prone position, and worsens during feeding or crying. The cry is normal.

Direct laryngoscopy shows an elongated epiglottis that is curled upon itself, making it appear omega (Ω)-shaped. Other features include floppy aryepiglottic folds and prominent arytenoids.

Stridor is noisy respiration produced by turbulent airflow through narrowed air passages. Stridor may be heard during inspiration, expiration or both

  • Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of the supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess.
  • Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi, e.g. bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis.
  • Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of the glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea, e.g. laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis.

Treatment of Laryngomalacia:

  • Mostly, it self corrects by 2 years of age.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with a mild cold. On examination, he is found to have adenoid facies. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Adenoid facies is a characteristic look seen in chronic adenoiditis. The treatment of choice in chronic adenoiditis is adenoidectomy with coblation.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

Management:

Definitive management is adenoidectomy. The treatment of choice is coblation adenoidectomy because it removes the tissue and prevents hemorrhage via radiofrequency ablation while curettage and microdebridement needs further cauterisation to control bleeding points. Older methods of classical adenoidectomy via mouth has been replaced by these newer techniques as the older methods were blind procedure

questions.text: An 8 weeks pregnant woman, working in an industry consults a doctor.  According to the ESI act, what is the duration of maternity leave that she can get?

choices.text: 28 weeks, starting from 4 weeks after delivery
26 weeks, starting from 8 weeks before delivery

questions.solution:
According to ESI act, this pregnant woman is entitled to a leave of 26 weeks, starting 8 weeks preceding the expected date of delivery.

According to The Employees State Insurance Act and its amendments, pregnant ladies can receive benefits in cash for confinement/miscarriage or sickness arising out of the same or premature birth of a child or miscarriage. This includes maternity leave for

  • 26 weeks of which not more than 8 weeks shall be preceding the expected date of her delivery.
  • 6 weeks in case of miscarriage.
  • 30 days for sickness arising out of being in the family way, premature delivery or medical termination of pregnancy.
  • Women having 2 or more surviving children shall be allowed maternity leave of 12 weeks of which not more than 6 weeks should be before the expected date of her delivery.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

  • The act defines factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 
  • Age of employment –  prohibition children of < 14 years from working.

    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours
    • They are allowed to take leave once in every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days
  • Hours of work for adults: maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day, if working overtime then it should be no more than 60 hrs per week
  • Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person
  • Safety and Welfare measures:
    • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
    • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
    • > 250 Workers – Canteen
    • > 50 Workers- Crèche*

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law which has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers- 12 weeks to 26 weeks
  • Working mothers, already with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

 

*for fifty women worker after the 1976 amendment.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the Michaelis-Menten graph?

choices.text: Km is directly proportional to substrate concentration
Km is directly proportional to enzyme concentration
Km is indirectly proportional to substrate concentration
Km has no relation to substrate concentration

questions.solution:
The Michaelis-Menten equation/graph represents the enzymatic rate (Km) at different substrate concentrations i.e Km is directly proportional to substrate concentration

For a typical enzyme, as the substrate concentration increases, initial velocity (Vi) increases until it reaches a maximum value Vmax. With further increase in the substrate concentration, the enzyme is said to be “saturated” with the substrate and the velocity remains the same. Hence, the shape of the curve that relates to the velocity of the reaction to substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates mathematically the relationship between Vi and [S] i.e,

Vi = Vmax ×[S]/Km+[S]

The Michaelis constant (Km) is the substrate concentration at which Vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2).

The plot of initial reaction velocity against substrate concentration is hyperbolic.

The correct sequence of muscles used are Ischiocavernosus contraction-External urethral sphincter relaxation- Bulbospongiosus contraction.

There are 2 stages involved in this process - emission of the sperms into the prostatic urethra and ejaculation.

1.Emission:

  • The sperm produced in the testes is brought into the urethra with contraction of the vas deferens and the ampulla and reach the seminal vesicles.

  • The filling of the internal urethra with semen elicits sensory signals that are transmitted through the pudendal nerves to the sacral regions of the cord, giving
    the feeling of sudden fullness in the internal genital organs.
  • These sensory signals further exciter rhythmic contraction of the internal genital organs and cause contraction of the ischiocavernosus to further move the semen into the prostatic urethra.
  • Retrograde ejaculation is prevented by the contraction of the internal urethral sphincter and relaxation of external urethral sphincter to help push the semen into the spongy urethra.
  • The bulbocavernosus muscles contracts and compress the bases of the penile erectile tissue and cause rhythmic wave like increases in pressure in the erectile tissue of the penis and the genital ducts and urethra, which move the semen from the urethra to the exterior which is called ejaculation.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy has been observed by his parents to be increasingly clumsy for the past 6 months. On physical examination, there is a cauliflower-like growth in the left eye alongside leukocoria and an absent red reflex. A diagnosis was made and enucleation was done. The microscopic appearance of the specimen shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histology, clinical history and gross specimen point towards a diagnosis of retinoblastoma.

Retinoblastoma is due to mutation in the Rb gene located on chromosome 13q14.

Retinoblastoma was the first cancer known to be directly associated with a genetic abnormality.

Clinical features of retinoblastoma:

  • Present within the first two years of life
  • Leukocoria 
  • Strabismus
  • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma
  • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis.
  • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases.
  • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular involvement is rare.

Signs:

  • An intraretinal tumour is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often with white flecks of calcification.
  • An endophytic tumour projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel.
  • An exophytic tumour forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal detachment.

Investigations:

  • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria.
  • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope
  • MRI of the orbit + brain is the investigation of choice.

 The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with a history of discomfort while swallowing food. She has no history of fever, sore throat, or smoking but has a history of Marfan's syndrome in her father. On examination of the oral cavity, there is unilateral swelling of the tonsils along with pulsation. What is the most likely cause of the swelling?
questions.solution:
The history of Marfan's syndrome( autosomal dominant disease) along with the pulsation of the tonsils is suggestive of an extracranial internal carotid artery aneurysm.

Even though the tonsils are supplied by the external carotid artery branches an internal carotid artery aneurysm can push the tonsil medially which gives the pulsation. The external carotid artery is more superficial in its course and would not lead to the medial displacement of the tonsils.

The internal carotid artery which gives no branches in the cervical region can cause kinks, elbowing, etc which leads to aneurysms when it lies close to the pharynx. In children, the tonsillo-carotid distance increases with growth to a maximum value of 25 mm.

Note: A common differential in a unilateral swelling of the tonsil is Quinsy (peritonsillar abscess) which requires incision and drainage as the treatment. Hence aneurysms need to be ruled out before the procedure as trauma to the internal carotid artery can be devastating since it supplies the brain too.

questions.text: What is the vertebral level of the abdominal plane labelled 2?
questions.solution:
The plane marked 2 in the given image is the subcostal plane. It is at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The subcostal plane is an anatomical reference plane used in clinical and surgical practice. It is defined as a horizontal plane passing through the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage bilaterally. The 10th costal cartilage corresponds approximately to the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

The costal cartilages are extensions of the ribs that articulate with the sternum anteriorly. The 10th costal cartilage is the cartilage of the 10th rib.

In the given image, structure 2 represents the subcostal plane, which corresponds to the level of the lower border of the 10th costal cartilage. Since the 10th costal cartilage is at the level of the upper border of L3, it indicates that the subcostal plane is also at the level of the upper border of L3.

Related Pearl: Abdominal planes and their landmarks

Planes that divide the abdomen into 9 regions

  • Horizontal planes 
    • L3 - Subcostal plane (between 10th costal cartilages). Corresponds to the 3rd part of the duodenum
    • L5 - Transtubercular plane (between tubercles of iliac crests). Corresponds to the origin of Inferior vena cava. 
  • Vertical planes (Paramedian or lateral planes)
    • Mid-clavicular point to mid-inguinal point on both sides 

The nine regions of the abdomen include:

  • Left hypochondriac, Epigastric, Right hypochondriac
  • Left lumbar, Umbilical (Central), Right lumbar
  • Left iliac, Hypogastric (Suprapubic), Right iliac

Other planes and angles in the abdomen

  • Transpyloric (Addison's) plane passes midway between the suprasternal notch and the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
  • The supracristal plane passing through the highest point of the iliac crest on both sides. Posteriorly, it corresponds to the level of the L4 body or L4/5 disc and its spinous process. It is an important landmark when performing a lumbar puncture or spinal injection. The bifurcation of the abdominal aorta lies approximately in this plane.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cyst on the neck anterior to the sternocleidomastoid at the junction of the upper and middle third of the muscle. This cyst is due to the persistence of which of the following embryological clefts?
questions.solution:
A cyst presenting at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border is most likely a branchial cyst. It develops from the vestigial remnants of the second branchial cleft.

Branchial cyst is most commonly seen at the junction of the upper and middle third of the sternomastoid muscle at its anterior border. It is usually lined by squamous epithelium and contains thick, turbid fluid full of cholesterol crystals. It is fluctuant and may transilluminate to a lesser extent when it contains clear fluid.

A branchial fistula may be acquired or congenital. The congenital fistula is seen at the junction of the middle and lower third of the sternomastoid. An acquired fistula is usually seen in cases of incomplete surgery for the branchial cyst or spontaneous rupture, and it is seen at the same site as the cyst.

questions.text: Postmortem examination of a dead body reveals contraction of the hands with absent primary relaxation. What is this suggestive of?
questions.solution:
Postmortem examination of a dead body with contraction of the hands and the absence of primary relaxation is suggestive of cadaveric spasm.

Cadaveric spasm/Instantaneous rigor is a phenomenon where a group of muscles that are in a state of contraction at the time of death remains contracted after death till molecular death occurs. It occurs immediately after death. There is no stage of primary relaxation. 

It is most commonly seen in voluntary muscles, especially hands. It is seen in cases of death associated with emotional disturbances like cases of excitement, fear, severe pain, and exhaustion at the time of death. It is an antemortem phenomenon and it indicates the manner of death and not the time since death.

 

Other options: 

Option A: Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. The order of appearance of rigor mortis: Myocardium of the heart is affected first. Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. It starts in the eyelids, neck, lower jaw, and muscles of the face and progresses downwards to involve the muscles of the chest, upper limbs, abdomen, and lower limbs. The fingers and toes are affected last.

Option B: Livor mortis/Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the dermis. It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to the stagnation of blood in the vessels of the dependent parts due to the effect of gravity. 

Option D: Algor mortis/postmortem cooling is one of the early changes occurring after death. The body loses heat mainly by conduction and convection after death.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 30-year-old male with cervical lymphadenopathy showed the following picture. The diagnosis is_____.
questions.solution:
In the picture given above, Reed–Sternberg (RS) cells are seen, which is a pathognomonic feature of Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL).

Reed–Sternberg cells :

  • RS cells are large and either multinucleated or have a bilobed nucleus (thus resembling an "owl's eye" appearance) with prominent eosinophilic inclusion-like nucleoli.
  • The RS cell is clonal in origin and arises from the germinal center B cells but typically has lost most B-cell gene expression and function.
  • Reed Sternberg cells are not diagnostic for any condition since they are seen in many conditions such as:
    • Hodgkin’s lymphoma
    • Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma (commonly in immunoblastic type)
    • Infectious mononucleosis
    • Sarcomas

Hodgkin's lymphoma:

  • The patient commonly presents with palpable, firm, rubbery, non-tender lymphadenopathy in the cervical or supraclavicular region. Systemic symptoms that are classified as B symptoms including Hodgkin's lymphoma are persistent fever (>100.4ºF), drenching night sweats, and unexplained weight loss of >10% body weight over the past 6 months.
  • It is characterized by a variable number of RS cells surrounded by an inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils in different proportions, depending on the HL histologic subtype.
  • The interaction between the RS cell and these background inflammatory cells with their associated cytokine release is important in the development and progression of HL.

Option A: A peripheral blood smear showing numerous Auer rods in the cytoplasm of progranulocytes is characteristic of acute myeloid leukemia (AML). There is also the presence of bilobed nuclei and multiple coarse azurophilic granules. 

Option C: Histopathology of human papillomavirus lesion shows koilocytes, perinuclear halo, multinucleation, and acanthosis. 

Option D: In chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) the peripheral smear contains a large number of monotonous, uniform-looking, mature lymphocytes, which is often described as a convent-girl appearance.

  • Mononuclear variant: Mixed cellularity and Lymphocyte rich

  • L&H/Lymphohistiocytic/Popcorn Variant: Lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does not form a grey-white membrane over the tonsils ?
questions.solution:
Ludwig’s angina does not cause a grey-white membrane over the tonsils. It is the submandibular space infection.

D/D for membrane over tonsil:

  • Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms
  • Diphtheria
  • Infectious mononucleosis
  • Vincent’s angina
  • Leukemia
  • Candida
  • Agranulocytosis
  • Malignancy
  • Aphthous ulcer
  • Traumatic ulcer

Ludwig’s Angina is the infection of submandibular space.

Submandibular space lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of mouth and the tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other side. It is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle:

  • Sublingual compartment (above the mylohyoid).
  • Submaxillary and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid).

Both compartments freely communicate in the midline with the opposite side. Therefore infection rapidly becomes bilateral.

Dental infections are the most common cause and account for 80% of the cases.

Clinical features:

  • Marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus.
  • When infection is localized to the sublingual space, structures in the floor of the mouth are swollen and tongue seems to be pushed up and back.
  • When the infection spreads to submaxillary space, submental and submandibular regions become swollen, tender and impart woody-hard feel.
  • Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess.
  • The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward threatening the airway.

Treatment:

  • Systemic antibiotics.
  • Incision and drainage of an abscess.
  • Tracheostomy, if there is severe obstruction of airway.

questions.text:
A patient comes with a history of category 3 dog bites. He received prophylaxis for a monkey bite 6 months back. What is the next step in management?

RIG- Rabies immunoglobulin

choices.text: Wound cleaning+ rabies vaccine on day 0 & 3

questions.solution:
This patient should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.

In India, monkeys are known to transmit rabies. Hence the national rabies control program advises a full course of PEP for monkey bites. This patient who was bitten by a monkey 6 months back would have received PEP for rabies. 

Management of a new dog bite in a previously immunized individual with either pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) or post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is as follows:

  • Category I: Wound treatment only
  • Category II/ III:
    • Wound treatment with soap and running water for 15 min and apply antiseptic
    • Receive Anti-rabies vaccine (ARV) 2 doses ID (0.1 ml, 1 site)/ 2 doses IM (1 VIAL, 1 site) on days 0 and 3.

Rabies immunoglobulin is not given for any category in case they have completed a full course of PEP.

*Note: In developing countries like India, the vaccination status of animals alone, doesn't play a significant role in determining the initiation of prophylaxis in humans.

Related Pearl: Rabies vaccines and immunoglobulins schedules

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India:

WHO category II or III exposures should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) immediately.

One intradermal (ID) dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one intramuscular (IM) dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • Passive immunization
  • Single-dose; after initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Alternatives for RIG- WHO recommends monoclonal antibodies (mAb) as a 'cocktail' containing at least two antibodies against the rabies virus.

Administration of RIG:

  • RIG should be administered into or around the wound site or sites.
  • The remaining RIG, if any, should be injected IM at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration.
  • RIG may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.

Prioritization of RIG allocation (numbered according to priority order):

  1. Multiple bites
  2. Deep wounds
  3. Bites to head, neck, and hands
  4. Patients with severe immunodeficiency
  5. Confirmed/probable rabies in biting animal
  6. Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat

Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP)

PrEP is considered in the following conditions:

  • High-risk groups- laboratory staff, wildlife wardens, veterinarians, animal handlers, and travelers to endemic regions.
  • Remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult
  • Areas where dog bite incidence is >5% per year
  • Areas where vampire bat rabies is known to be present.

Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of two intramuscular (IM) or two intradermal (ID) doses. These are given on days 0 and 3.

  • Adults - the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm
  • Young children (under 1 year of age)- Administration into the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended.
  • Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.

For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous completion of PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:

  • Proper wound management should be done.
  • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
  • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.

Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP within the last three months.

The following cases are treated as fresh cases and given full PEP:

  • Those who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccines of unproven potency
  • Those who cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment

questions.text: A 61-year-old university professor presents with a loss of vision in his left eye. He describes the sensation as a curtain being drawn over his affected eye. In addition, 7 days ago the patient noticed what he described as flashing lights and floaters. He gives a history of having cataract surgery in the same eye 3 weeks ago. A B-scan image of his left eye is shown below. What could be his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the B-scan suggest a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. It is due to the accumulation of fluid between neurosensory retina(NSR) and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) due to a retinal tear.

Definition of retinal detachment: The separation of the neurosensory retina from the RPE.

Types of Retinal detachment:

A. Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment- fluid accumulates after a break (tear) occurs in the retina.

  • Causes:
    • High myopes
    • Retinoschisis-splitting of neurosensory retina plus vitreous degeneration
      • Typical retinoschisis-split at the level of the outer plexiform layer
      • Atypical retinoschisis-split at the level of the nerve fiber layer
    • Trauma
    • Pseudophakia
    • Aphakia
  • The most dangerous type of retinal break is horseshoe tear.
  • The most dangerous location of retinal break is the supero-temporal retina. 
  • Clinical features
    • Photopsia-flashes of light due to vitreoretinal traction at the site of the break
    • Floaters
    • Visual field defect- a black curtain/veil in front of the eye
  • Signs
    • Hypotony- as the liquefied vitreous in the subretinal space is absorbed through the RPE.
    • Shafers sign-pigments in the anterior vitreous (tobacco dusting) are a feature of fresh retinal detachment.
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is corrugated with undulations.
  • Treatment
    • Prophylactic laser barrage
    • Scleral buckling
    • Pneumatic retinopexy
    • Pars plana vitrectomy 

B. Tractional retinal detachment: Fibro-vascular membranes in the vitreous due to long-standing retinal neovascularization exert traction on the retina. 

  • Causes
    • Proliferative diabetic retinopathy
    • Central retinal venous occlusion
    • Eales disease
    • Retinopathy of Prematurity(ROP)
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is concave in configuration. No breaks are seen
  • Treatment
    • Pars plana vitrectomy with endo photocoagulation. 

C. Exudative retinal detachment: Exudative fluid from the choroid, collects in the subretinal space leading to retinal detachment.

  • Causes
    • Inflammatory conditions like choroiditis, posterior scleritis
    • Choroidal tumours like melanoma
    • Toxaemia of pregnancy
    • Malignant hypertension
    • Coats disease
  • Clinical features
    • Floaters due to vitritis but no photopsia
    • Visual field defect
  • Signs
    • The detached retina is convex in configuration. The surface is smooth. No break is seen.
    • Shifting fluid is seen.
  • Treatment
    • Systemic steroids
    • Treatment of the cause

questions.text: 3 months following cataract surgery, a patient comes with complaints of decreased visual acuity. On examination, posterior capsular opacification is seen. What type of laser can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given history mentions decreased visual acuity 3 months post-cataract surgery and the presence of posterior capsular opacification is suggestive of after-cataract. A posterior capsulotomy (creating a hole in the posterior capsule) using an Nd: YAG laser is the mainstay of treatment.

Posterior capsular opacification, otherwise known as after cataract/secondary cataract, is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. It occurs due to the proliferation of lens epithelial cells that have been left out inside the capsular bag after cataract surgery. The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Symptoms of after cataract include:

  • Reduction of visual acuity
  • Slowly worsening blurring
  • Glare and occasionally monocular diplopia

They can present in different patterns such as:

  • Elschnig's pearls: present as vacuolated (pearl-type) grape-like clusters of swollen cells 
  • Soemmering's ring: present as a white annular proliferation that is formed at the periphery of the capsular bag.
  • Fibrosis type: present as fibroblastic metaplasia of the epithelial cells 

Treatment:

  • Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy: The laser used in posterior capsulotomy is Nd: YAG laser (1064 nm) whose principle is photodisruption. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues creating an opening.
  • Surgical treatment: Posterior capsular opacification is managed by creating an opening on the posterior capsule along the visual axis, a procedure called a posterior capsulotomy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. On examination,  a reddish mass was seen behind the tympanic membrane and an audible bruit is heard over the mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinnie test was negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a woman with progressive conductive hearing loss, tinnitus , reddis mass behind the tympanic membrane and audible bruit heard over the mastoid suggests a diagnosis of a ‘glomus tumor’.

Glomus tumor:

The cell of origin in the glomus tumor is paraganglionic cells (not perivascular cells). These cells are derived from the neural crest. They are paragangliomas of the glomus bodies found in the mastoid.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear.

It is of 2 types:

  • Glomus jugulare: It arises from the dome of the jugular bulb causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.
  • Glomus tympanicum: It arises from the promontory of the middle ear and causes aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

The rule of 10 is seen in the glomus tumor. It comprises of

  • 10% familial
  • 10% multicentric
  • 10% functional

It is 5 times more common in women. Common presenting features include:

  • Progressive conductive hearing loss
  • Tinnitus in glomus tumors is pulsatile, of swishing character, synchronous with a pulse, and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Audible bruit heard over the mastoid with a stethoscope in all stages

Investigations would include:

  • Phelp's sign-on CECT scan helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumor by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter.
  • MRI gives the soft tissue extent of the tumor.
  • Four vessel angiography is necessary when the CT head shows the involvement of a jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension.
  • A biopsy is never done since it’s a highly vascular tumor.
