questions.text: During a vaccination drive, a male patient asks the presiding doctor if the recommended vaccine can lead to impotency. What type of barrier will the doctor be addressing?
questions.solution:
The doctor in this case is trying to address the cultural barrier.

This individual thinks that vaccination can cause impotency. This may be due to his understanding, beliefs or knowledge towards vaccination which are all part of cultural barrier.

A failure in communication between educators and the community affects health education, counselling and motivating people. They can be of the following types:

  1. Physiological barrier due to difficulties in hearing, expression
  2. Psychological barriers like emotional disturbances, neurosis, levels of intelligence, language or comprehension difficulties.
  3. Environmental barriers like noise, invisibility, congestion
  4. Cultural barriers include illiteracy, levels of knowledge and understanding, customs, beliefs, religion, attitudes, economic and social class differences, language variations, and cultural difficulties.

questions.text: A pregnant woman from a rural area registers under Janani Suraksha Yojana. Which of the following services would not be provided to her under this scheme?

choices.text: Safe motherhood services under Vandematharam scheme

questions.solution:
The Janani Suraksha Yojana (JSY) does not provide STD counseling.

Janani Suraksha Yojana is a safe motherhood intervention launched under National Rural Health Mission (NRHM) to reduce maternal and neonatal mortality by promoting institutional delivery among poor pregnant women. The services provided by the JSY are:

  • Cash is disbursed to the mother at the institution for having an institutional delivery.
  • Safe motherhood services (IFA tablets, Tt vaccination) under the Vandemataram scheme. 
  • Village health and nutrition day
  • Maternal death review
  • Pregnancy tracking: ASHA worker/Anganwadi Worker (AWW) or any other link worker help in monitoring antenatal check-ups, and post-delivery care.
  • Safe abortion services: mifepristone followed by misoprostol and manual vacuum aspiration.

questions.text: A male presented with the following findings which he noticed when he woke up in the morning. There was no history of associated fever or rash. What is the drug of choice for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy and steroids are the drug of choice for Bell's palsy

Bell's palsy is a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve and involves the ipsilateral side of the upper and lower halves of the face. Bell's palsy is idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. The onset of Bell's palsy is fairly abrupt. 

If the patient attempts to close the eye, the eyeball would turn up and out - this is known as the Bell's phenomenon. Decreased tearing, hyperacusis, taste disturbances, otalgia, weakness of the facial muscles, poor eyelid closure, etc can be seen. When the patient smiles, the face becomes distorted and lateralizes to the side opposite the palsy. Flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side affected by palsy. 

Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days. The use of artificial tears and covering the eye at night prevents corneal drying.

Approximately 85 to 95% of patients recover fully. The presence of incomplete paralysis in the first week is the most favourable prognostic sign. Recurrences are seen in some cases. Bell's palsy is a diagnosis of exclusion. All other possible causes of facial paralysis should be ruled out by investigation.

questions.text: In the liver, the Apo-B gene is completely translated to ApoB-100 and in the intestine, it is translated to ApoB-48. Which of the following mechanism explains this?
questions.solution:
The production of apolipoprotein (ApoB-48) in the intestine and ApoB-100 in the liver is the result of RNA editing in the intestine.

RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation by post-transcriptional modification. As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by the insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in the 3’ to 5’ direction.

The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves RNA editing.

RNA editing in apoB synthesis:
  • In the liver, the apoB gene is transcribed to mRNA, which is then translated to apoB-100.
  • In the intestine, the same apoB gene is transcribed to the same mRNA. But now, the mRNA undergoes editing by an enzyme cytidine deaminase, which converts the CAA codon in the mRNA to UAA (stop codon) at a single specific site. Here, a sense codon is changed to a nonsense codon by post-transcriptional deamination of cytosine to uracil. This edited mRNA translates to apoB-48.

The image below shows the RNA editing in the Apo-B gene.

 

DNA rearrangement, alternate splicing, and RNA interference also alter the gene expression but are not the basis of apoB-48 tissue-specific production.

questions.text: Identify the given histology slide:
questions.solution:
The above image shows pancreatic islet cells. Islet of Langerhans makes up the endocrine part of the pancreas.

Islets are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers, and containing numerous fenestrated capillaries. There is a delicate capsule around each islet. They are paler than the surrounding exocrine cells, as they have less rough endoplasmic reticulum.

The image given below shows the histology of the pancreas.

The islets of Langerhans contain four major and two minor cell types:

Four main types are β, α, δ, and PP (pancreatic polypeptide) cells:

  • α or A cells- located peripherally and secrete glucagon 
  • β or B cells- located centrally and produce insulin 
  • δ or D cells- scattered between beta cells and secrete somatostatin
  • PP cells- are present in islets and also in the exocrine pancreas. They secrete a pancreatic polypeptide, which exerts several gastrointestinal effects, such as stimulation of secretion of gastric and intestinal enzymes and inhibition of intestinal motility. 

Minor cell types:

  • D1 cells secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), a hormone that induces glycogenolysis and hyperglycemia. It also stimulates gastrointestinal fluid secretion and causes secretory diarrhea.
  • Enterochromaffin cells synthesize serotonin and are the source of pancreatic tumors that cause carcinoid syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. The structure of lymph nodes consists of an outer cortex and inner medulla. The cortex contains an aggregation of B-lymphocytes (primary follicles) and quiescent secondary follicles with a pale central germinal center.

The inner medulla consists of medullary cords (lymphocytes and plasma cells) and medullary sinuses. Between the cortex and medulla, there is an ill-defined zone called the paracortex, which contains T lymphocytes.

The image given below shows the histology of the lymph node. 

Option B: Glomerulus is a rounded tuft of anastomosing capillaries. The glomerular capillary wall is the filtering membrane and consists of fenestrated endothelial cells, basement membrane, and visceral epithelial cells called podocytes, which contain foot processes.

The image given below shows the histology of the glomerulus.

Option C: Spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ. It contains round white pulp surrounded by red pulp. The white pulp is made up of aggregations of lymphocytes that surround a small artery or arterioles.

The red pulp is a modified lymphoid tissue infiltrated with all the cells of circulating blood. It is like a sponge permeated by spaces (splenic sinusoids) lined by reticular cells. The zone of red pulp immediately surrounding white pulp is the marginal zone. This zone has a rich network of sinusoids.

The image given below shows the histology of the spleen.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient presents to the OPD with complaints of shortness of breath and tiredness. There is no history of reactive airway disease or heart diseases previously. She has a history of breast cancer for which breast conservation surgery and chemoradiation were done. On examination, there were engorged neck veins and JVP showed rapid x and y descent and Chest Xray is as below.Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the JVP findings of rapid X and Y descent  are suggestive of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis:

  • It is the condition where a thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified pericardium restricts the diastolic filling of the heart.
  • In developing countries, infectious etiologies like tuberculosis or viral infections are the most common cause of this condition.
  • Cardiac surgery and radiation therapy are also common causes.
  • Other causes include connective tissue disease, uremia, neoplasm, or idiopathic.
  • Clinically the patients present with dyspnea, orthopnea, and fatigue.
  • JVP findings - There is a rapid 'x' and 'y' descent. The rapid 'y' descent is more prominent and reflects rapid early ventricular diastolic filling. This occurs due to the constricting pericardium, increasing the atrial pressures.

Diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis is difficult and is confirmed by multiple investigations
  • Hallmark findings of pericardial constriction are pericardial thickening, calcification, and abnormal ventricular diastolic function.
  • The X-ray can be normal or there may be non-specific cardiac enlargement, calcification, and roughened cardiac outline.
  • Echo can assess the hemodynamic function but it is accurate in identifying pericardial thickening.
  • CT and MRI are more sensitive investigations.
  • CT has an edge over MRI as it can detect calcification associated with this condition.
  • Pericardial thickness of > 4mm along with clinical features of constriction is highly suggestive of this diagnosis.
  • Cardiac MR may show diastolic septal bounce.
  • Hepatomegaly and ascites can be seen associated with this condition.

Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent, and Kussmaul's sign. Normally, the venous pressure should fall by at least 3 mmHg with inspiration. Kussmaul’s sign is defined by either a rise or a lack of fall of the JVP with inspiration.

Other important conditions and their JVP tracings are

  • In Cardiac tamponade, the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing of the patient will have a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.
  • Atrioventricular block will have cannon a waves
  • Atrial fibrillation will have absent a wave
  • Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent
  • Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD with fever, severe pain, and swelling of the left eye. He was bitten by a dog over the eye a few days back. On examination, there is mild proptosis with restriction of ocular movements. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of orbital cellulitis.

It is the acute inflammation of the soft tissues of the orbit behind the orbital septum. It can occur due to exogenous infection (penetrating injuries) or extension of an endogenous infection (dental infection). 

It presents with fever, severe pain, and eye swelling which increases with movement, chemosis, axial proptosis, and restriction of ocular movements. Complications include subperiosteal abscess, orbital abscess, cavernous sinus thrombosis, and general septicemia.

Option B: Endophthalmitis is defined as the inflammation of the inner structures of the eyeball, i.e., uveal tissue and retina, associated with the pouring of exudates into the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber, and posterior chamber.

Option C: Panophthalmitis is an intense purulent inflammation of the whole eyeball, including Tenon’s capsule.

Option D: Preseptal cellulitis refers to infection of the subcutaneous tissues anterior to the orbital septum. In this condition, proptosis is absent and ocular movements are normal.

questions.text: A young boy presented with fissured tongue, lips, and lesions in the angle of the mouth as shown below. On investigation, he had low RBC glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin is deficient here?
questions.solution:
Clinical presentation of this patient showing cheilosis and stomatitis, combined with low RBC glutathione reductase activity is consistent with riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency.

The deficiency state of riboflavin is characterized by the following signs and symptoms:

  1. Cheilosis: pallor in the angle of mouth and fissuring of lips, which extends radially to skin
  2. Glossitis: tongue becomes smooth, loss of papilla (magenta-colored tongue)
  3. Eyes: keratitis, conjunctivitis, corneal vascularisation
  4. Other features: Seborrheic dermatitis, Anemia

The nutritional status of riboflavin can be assessed by measuring the activity of the RBC glutathione reductase, by FAD added in vitro (this test is specific for riboflavin deficiency).
